title: Battle of Shipka Pass IV: Russian and Bulgarian forces defeat the Ottoman Empire.
Humbert I becomes King of Italy.
Battle of Philippopolis: Russian troops defeat the Turks.
Benjamin Disraeli orders the British fleet to the Dardanelles.
The revolutionary Vera Zasulich shoots at Fyodor Trepov, the Governor of Saint Petersburg.
''The Yale News'' becomes the first daily college newspaper in the United States.
Turkey agrees to an armistice at Adrianople.
Greece declares war on Turkey.
Pope Pius IX dies after a 31½ year reign (the longest definitely confirmed).
The British fleet enters Turkish waters and anchors off Istanbul Russia threatens to occupy Istanbul but does not carry out the threat.
The Lincoln County War begins in Lincoln County, New Mexico.
The phonograph is patented by Thomas Edison.
Pope Leo XIII succeeds Pope Pius IX as the 256th pope.
Anti-Russian demonstrations occur in Hyde Park, London.
Mississippi State University is created by the Mississippi Legislature (under the name The Agricultural and Mechanical College of the State of Mississippi).
Bulgaria regains its independence from the Ottoman Empire.
The Treaty of San Stefano concludes the Russo-Turkish War
The UK frigate ''Eurydice'' sinks, killing 300.
Russia rejects a British proposal to lay the San Stefano treaty before a European congress.
In anticipation of war with Russia, Disraeli mobilizes the reserves and calls up Indian troops to Malta.
The Stawell Gift is run for the first time.
The Washburn quotAquot Mill in Minneapolis, Minnesota explodes, killing 18.
The Tokyo Stock Exchange is established
Universal Postal Union (UPU)
Cyprus Convention: The Ottoman Empire cedes Cyprus to the United Kingdom but retains the nominal title.
The League of Prizren is established.
July 12 ampndash The Congress of Berlin convenes to discuss the Ottoman Empire.
Sallie Gardner at a Gallop, the first motion picture ever made was recorded on this day.
U.S. Coastal Survey renamed U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey.

Adolf Erik Nordenskiöld leaves Karlskrona on a voyage that will make him the first to navigate the Northern Sea Route, a shipping lane from the Atlantic Ocean to the Pacific Ocean along the Siberian coast.
A match race between champion thoroughbred racehorses Ten Broeck and Mollie McCarty draws more than 30,000 fans to Louisville and insprires the folk song, Molly and Tenbrooks.
The Treaty of Berlin makes Serbia, Montenegro and Romania completely independent.

In California, the poet and American West outlaw calling himself quotBlack Bartquot makes his last clean getaway when he steals a safe box from a Wells Fargo stagecoach. The empty box is found later with a taunting poem inside.
The Salvation Army quotfoundation deedquot is signed.
The Wallingford Tornado of 1878, the deadliest tornado in Connecticut history, destroys the town of Wallingford, killing 34 people and injuring 70 or more.
Uyedineniya Island is discovered in the Kara Sea by Norwegian explorer Captain Edvard Holm Johannesen.
Over 640 die when the crowded pleasure boat {{SS|Princess Alice|1865|2}} collides with the ''Bywell Castle'' in the River Thames.
''The Hindu'', an Indian newspaper, is founded.
The ship ''Priscilla'' arrives in Hawaii from Funchal, Madeira, marking the beginning of the Portuguese immigration to the Hawaiian Islands (1878–1913).
Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University (Virginia Tech) opens as Virginia Agricultural and Mechanical College.
The world's first recorded floodlit football fixture is played at Bramall Lane in Sheffield.
John A. Macdonald returns to office as Prime Minister of Canada.

The first assassination attempt is made against Umberto I of Italy by anarchist Giovanni Passannante, armed with a dagger. The King survived with a slight wound in one arm. Prime minister Benedetto Cairoli blocked the aggressor, receiving an injury to one of his legs.
The Second Afghan War commences when the British attack Ali Masjid in the Khyber Pass.
The Specie Resumption Act takes effect. The Greenback is valued the same as gold for the first time since the Civil War.
Fred Spofforth claims the first Hat-trick in Test cricket.
The Anglo-Zulu War begins.
Anglo-Zulu War ampndash Battle of Isandlwana: Zulu troops massacre British troops.  At Rorke's Drift, outnumbered British soldiers drive the attackers away after hours of fighting.
At New York City's Madison Square Garden, the first artificial ice rink in North America opens.
Chilean troops disembark at Antofagasta, Chile,  at the time a Bolivian port. The event marks the beginning of the War of the Pacific between Chile and the joint forces of Peru and Bolivia.
Women's rights: American President Rutherford B. Hayes signs a bill allowing female attorneys to argue cases before the Supreme Court of the United States.
In Utica, New York, Frank Woolworth opens the first of many 5 and 10-cent Woolworth stores.
The discovery of saccharin is announced.
The United States Geological Survey is created.
Anglo-Zulu War ampndash Battle of Intombe: A British force over one-hundred strong is ambushed and destroyed by Zulu forces.
Prince Arthur, Duke of Connaught and Strathearn, third son of Queen Victoria, marries Princess Louise Margaret of Prussia.
March 14  ampndash Albert Einstein ampndash Theoretical physicist, philosopher and author who is widely regarded as one of the most influential scientists and intellectuals of all time was born.
Anglo-Zulu War ampndash Battle of Hlobane: British forces suffer a defeat.
Anglo-Zulu War ampndash Battle of Kambula: British forces defeat 20,000 Zulus.
The Spanish Socialist Worker's Party is founded in Casa Labra Pub (city of Madrid) by the historical Spanish workers' leader Pablo Iglesias.
The first group of 463 Indian indentured labourers arrive in Fiji abroad the ''Leonidas''.
Russia and the United Kingdom sign the Treaty of Gandamak, establishing an Afghan state.
New York City's Gilmore's Garden is renamed Madison Square Garden by William Henry Vanderbilt, and is opened to the public at 26th Street and Madison Avenue.
Napoléon Eugène, Prince Imperial (Napoléon IV), great-nephew of Napoléon Bonaparte, Bonapartist pretender to the throne, dies in Africa during the Anglo-Zulu War.
Sidney Faithorn Green, a priest in the Church of England, is tried and convicted for using Ritualist practices.
Anglo-Zulu War: The Anglo-Zulu War effectively ends at the Battle of Ulundi.
Doc Holliday kills for the first time after a man shoots up Holliday's New Mexico saloon.
The Virgin Mary, along with St. Joseph and St. John the Evangelist, allegedly appears in Knock, Ireland to local people.
The Octagon fire claims 12 victims in Dunedin, New Zealand.
Deadwood, South Dakota  fire: Two-thousand people left homeless. Three hundred buildings destroyed. Total loss of property is estimated at $3 million.
Meeker Massacre: Nathan Meeker and others are killed in an uprising at the White River Ute Indian Reservation in Colorado.
The Dual Alliance is formed by Germany and Austria-Hungary.
The Naval Battle of Angamos was fought during the naval stage of the War of the Pacific.
Sunderland Association Football Club formed in the North East Of England.
Using a filament of carbonized thread, Thomas Edison tests the first practical electric light bulb (it lasts 13½ hours before burning out).
The Tay Bridge disaster ampndash the central part of the Tay Rail Bridge in Dundee, Scotland collapses as a train passes over it, killing 75.
''The Pirates of Penzance'' is first performed in Paignton, Devon, England.
Thomas Edison demonstrates incandescent lighting to the public for the first time  in Menlo Park, New Jersey.
Wabash, Indiana becomes the first electrically lit city in the world.
April - The government of Cape Colony sets a deadline for the surrender of weapons by the Basuto people. Non-compliance leads to the Basuto Gun War.
In Menlo Park, New Jersey, Thomas Edison performs the first test of his electric railway.
June 1  ampndash Tinius Olsen awarded a United States Patent for the Little Giant Testing Machine
France annexes Tahiti.
Dorchester Penitentiary opens in Canada.
Abdur Rahman Khan becomes Emir of Afghanistan.
October ampampndash The ampquotBlizzard of 1880ampquot begins in North America.
The University of Southern California opens its doors to 53 students and 10 faculty.
Mexican soldiers kill Victorio, one of the greatest Apache military strategists.
The first stone is laid for the Clarkson Memorial in Wisbech.
U.S. presidential election, 1880: James Garfield defeats Winfield S. Hancock.
The first cash register is patented by James and John Ritty of Dayton, Ohio.
Cologne Cathedral is completed, after construction began in 1248, 632 years earlier.
The journal ''Science'' is founded by Thomas Edison.
Cocaine is isolated.
The Capuchin catacombs of Palermo are officially closed (there will be some burials afterwards).
The Department of Scientific Temperance Instruction of the Women's Christian Temperance Union is established.
Pierre Savorgnan de Brazza signs a treaty of protection with the chief on the large Teke tribe and begins to establish a French protectorate on the north bank of the Congo River.
Australian bushranger and bank robber Ned Kelly is hanged in Melbourne.
Vaudeville actress Lillian Russell makes her debut at Tony Pastor's Theatre in New York City.
First Boer War: The Action at Bronkhorstspruit results in a Boer victory over the British.
The Transvaal becomes a republic and Paul Kruger becomes its first president.
January 24 ampndash Siege of Geok Tepe: Russian troops under General Mikhail Skobelev defeat the Turkomans.

William Edward Forster, the chief secretary for Ireland, introduces his Coercion Bill, which temporarily suspended habeas corpus so that those people suspected of committing an offence could be detained without trial it goes through a long debate before it is accepted February 2.
Thomas Edison and Alexander Graham Bell form the Oriental Telephone Company.
The Parkfield Earthquake occurs.
Phoenix, Arizona is incorporated.
The first issue of the feminist newspaper ''La Citoyenne'' is published by Hubertine Auclert.
Kansas becomes the first U.S. state to prohibit all alcoholic beverages.
Inauguration of James A. Garfield as President of the United States.
Andrew Watson makes his Scotland debut as the world's first black international football player.
Alexander II of Russia is killed near his palace when a bomb is thrown at him.  He is succeeded by his son, Alexander III.
First Boer War comes to an end.
Spelman College is established.
The Four Dead in Five Seconds Gunfight erupts in El Paso, Texas.
Temuco, Chile is founded.
Anti-Semitic pogroms in Southern Russia start.
The University of Connecticut is founded as the Storrs Agricultural School.
Caulfield Grammar School is founded in Melbourne, Australia.
Billy the Kid escapes from his 2 jailers at the Lincoln County Jail in Mesilla, New Mexico, killing James Bell and Robert Ollinger before stealing a horse and riding out of town.
In North Africa, Tunisia becomes a French protectorate.
The Pacific island of Rotuma cedes to Great Britain, becoming a dependency of the Colony of Fiji.
The American Red Cross is established by Clara Barton.
The United States Tennis Association is established by  a small group of tennis club members.
The USS ''Jeannette'' is crushed in an Arctic Ocean ice pack.
The current Cincinnati Reds baseball team plays its first game.
James Garfield, President of the United States, is shot by Charles Julius Guiteau. The wound becomes infected killing Garfield on September 19.
In Alabama, the Tuskegee Institute opens.
Billy the Kid is shot and killed by Pat Garrett outside Fort Sumner.
American Indian Wars: Sioux chief Sitting Bull leads the last of his fugitive people in surrender to United States troops at Fort Buford in Montana.
The Boundary treaty of 1881 between Chile and Argentina is signed in Buenos Aires.
The Pretoria Convention peace treaty is signed, officially ending the war between the Boers and Britain.
The fifth hurricane of the Atlantic season hits Florida and the Carolinas, killing about 700.
The Thumb Fire in the U.S. state of Michigan destroys over a million acres (4,000ampnbspkm²) and kills 282 people.

Francis Howell High School (Howell Institute) in St. Charles, Missouri, and Stephen F. Austin High School in Austin, Texas open on the same day, putting them in a tie for the title of the oldest public high school west of the Mississippi River.
U.S. President James A. Garfield dies eleven weeks after being shot. Vice President Chester A. Arthur becomes the 21st President of the United States.
U.S. President Chester A. Arthur is sworn in.
Godalming in England becomes the first town to have its streets illuminated by electric light (hydroelectrically generated).
December 31 ampndash International Cotton Exposition in Atlanta, Georgia
The Gunfight at the O.K. Corral occurs in Tombstone, Cochise County, Arizona, USA.
''Judge'' (U.S. magazine) is first published.
The Clarkson Memorial in Wisbech is completed and unveiled to the public.
A meteorite strikes earth near the village of Großliebenthal, a few kilometers southwest of Odessa, Ukraine.
Ringtheaterbrand: At least 380 die in a fire at the Vienna Ringtheater.
Virgil Earp is ambushed in Tombstone and loses the use of his left arm.
P. T. Barnum purchases the elephant Jumbo.
Roderick Maclean fails to assassinate Queen Victoria.
British gunboats enter Monrovia, with Arthur Havelock demanding that Liberia cede disputed territory to the British colony of Sierra Leone.
Polygamy is made a felony by the Edmunds Act as passed by the U.S. Congress.
Robert Koch announces the discovery of the bacterium responsible for tuberculosis (''Mycobacterium tuberculosis'').
Republican Jules Ferry makes primary education in France free, non-clerical (laique) and obligatory.
The ''Knights of Columbus'' are established.
Old West outlaw Jesse James is shot in the back of the head and killed by Robert Ford.
Charles Stewart Parnell is released.
The quotInvinciblesquot (militant Irish republicans) kill Lord Frederick Cavendish, chief secretary for Ireland and permanent undersecretary T.H. Burke in Phoenix Park, Dublin
The ''Chinese Exclusion Act'' is the first important law which restricts immigration into the U.S.A.
The Triple Alliance is formed between Germany, Austria-Hungary and Italy.
A cyclone in the Arabian Sea causes flooding in Bombay harbor, leaving about 100,000 dead.
Battle of Embabo: The Shewan forces of Menelik defeat the Gojjame army.
The Urabi Revolt breaks out in Egypt against the Khedive and European influence in that country.
Anglo-French Convention of 1882 signed marking territorial boundaries between Guinea and Sierra Leone.
U.S. presidential assassin Charles Guiteau is hanged.
British troops occupy Alexandria and the Suez Canal.
Boers establish the republic of Stellaland in southern Africa.
Richard Wagner's opera ''Parsifal'' debuts at the Bayreuth Festspielhaus in Bavaria.
The Hebrew Moshava of Rishon Le-Zion is founded.
The U.S. Congress passes the 1882 Immigration Act.
Standard Oil of New Jersey is established.
The Married Women's Property Act 1882 receives royal assent in Britain it enables women to buy, own and sell property and to keep their own earnings.
Piotr Ilyitch Tchaikovsky's ''1812 Overture'' debuts in Moscow.

Thomas Edison flips the switch to the first commercial electrical power plant in history, lighting one square mile of lower Manhattan. This is considered by many as the day that began the electrical age.
The first United States Labor Day parade is held in New York City.
1882 Anglo-Egyptian War: British troops occupy Cairo, and Egypt becomes a British protectorate.

Great Comet of 1882: Her Majesty's Astronomer at the Cape, David Gill, reported watching the comet rise a few minutes before the Sun and described it as quotThe nucleus was then undoubtedly single, and certainly rather under than over 4″ in diameter in fact, as I have described it, it resembled very much a star of the 1st magnitude seen by daylight.quot
The Society for Ethical Culture of Chicago ampndash (currently the Ethical Humanist Society of Chicago) is founded by Felix Adler.
The University of the Punjab is founded in present day Pakistan.
The Nickel Plate Railroad opens for business.
Franklin Leslie shoots Billy Claiborne dead in the streets of Tombstone, Arizona.
The Royal Navy's HMS ''Flirt'' destroys Abari village in Niger.
The last transit of the planet Venus until 2004 occurs.
December ampampndash Zichron Yaakov is founded in northern Israel.
''Life'' magazine is founded is founded in New York City.
A fire at the Newhall Hotel in Milwaukee kills 73 people.
The Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act, establishing the United States civil service, is passed.
The first electric lighting system employing overhead wires begins service in Roselle, New Jersey (it was built by Thomas Edison).
The German composer Richard Wagner dies of a heart attack in Venice, Italy.
The ''Ladies Home Journal'' is published for the first time.
Alabama becomes the first U.S. state to enact an antitrust law.
The first vaudeville theater is opened, in Boston, Massachusetts.
The Hong Kong Observatory is formed.
The Gloucester City A.F.C. is formed.
Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property.
Oxygen is liquefied for the very first time.
Construction of the Swanage Railway begins.
Brooklyn Bridge is opened to traffic after 13 years of construction.
In New York City, a rumor that the Brooklyn Bridge is going to collapse causes a stampede which crushes 12 people.
Victoria Hall disaster: A rush for treats results in 183 children being asphyxiated in a concert hall in Sunderland, England.
In Milan, Italy the first central European electricity power station is inaugurated.

''The Black Arrow'' by Robert Louis Stevenson first appears as a serial in ''Young Folks A Boys' and Girls' Paper of Instructive and Entertaining Literature''. Stevenson completes the novel at the end of summer in France.
The ''SS Daphne'' disaster in Glasgow leaves 124 dead.
The world's first rodeo is held in Pecos, Texas.
Zulu King Cetshwayo barely escapes a rebel attack with his life.
August ampampndash King William's College is opened on the Isle of Man.
The last quagga dies at the Artis Magistra zoo in Amsterdam.
An F5 tornado strikes Rochester, Minnesota, leading to the creation of the Mayo Clinic.
August 28 ampndash Krakatoa or Krakatau volcano erupts at 10:02 AM (local time) 163 villages are destroyed, 36,380 killed.
Major Evelyn Baring becomes Consul-General of Egypt under British rule.
The Bombay Natural History Society is founded.
The University of Texas at Austin opens to students.

A consortium of flour mill operators in Minneapolis, Minnesota forms the Minneapolis, Sault Ste. Marie and Atlantic Railway as a means to get their product to the Great Lakes ports but avoid the high tariffs of Chicago.
Sydney Boys High School (the first boys' public school) is founded in Sydney, Australia.
The Boys' Brigade (the first uniformed youth organization in existence) is founded in Glasgow, Scotland.
The Orient Express begins operation.
The Supreme Court of the United States declares part of the Civil Rights Act of 1875 to be unconstitutional, allowing individuals and corporations to discriminate based on race.
Peru and Chile sign the Treaty of Ancón, by which the Tarapacá province is ceded to Chile, ending Peru's involvement in the War of the Pacific.
Cardiff University, Wales, opens (under the name of University College of South Wales and Monmouthshire).

Two Clan na Gael dynamite bombs explode in the London underground, injuring several people. The next day, Home Secretary Vernon Harcourt drafts 300 policemen to guard the underground and introduces the Explosives Bill.
Amsterdam: The first international colonial and export exhibition closes, having had over 1 million visitors.
American Old West: Self-described quotBlack Bart the Po-8quot makes his last stagecoach robbery, but leaves a handkerchief with a laundry mark that eventually leads to his capture.
Chile's National Library of Congress is founded.
U.S. and Canadian railroads institute 5 standard continental time zones, ending the confusion of thousands of local times.
Whitman College is chartered as a 4-year college in Walla Walla, Washington.
The Fabian Society is founded in London.
Gilbert amp Sullivan's ''Princess Ida'' has its première at the Savoy Theatre, London.
Dr William Price attempts to cremate the body of his infant son, Iesu Grist (Jesus Christ) Price, setting a legal precedent for cremation in the U.K.
The first edition of the ''Oxford English Dictionary'' is published.
The Derby County Football Club is founded
The Diocese of Madrid-Alcalá is founded.
The siege of Khartoum, Sudan begins (ends on January 26, 1885).
The Colchester earthquake, England, the UK's most destructive, occurs.
German protectorate in South-West Africa.

The eight-hour workday is first proclaimed by the Federation of Organized Trades and Labor Unions in the United States. May 1, called ''May Day'' or ''Labour Day'', is now a holiday recognized in almost every industrialized country.
Angelo Moriondo of Turin is granted a patent for an espresso machine.#33/256. ''Bollettino delle privative industriali del Regno d’Italia'' 2nd Series '''15''' (1884) pp. 635–655.
The Estonian flag is consecrated as the flag of the Estonian Students Society.
Germany takes possession of Togoland.
German administration in Cameroon.
Today's ''Courier'' records the first tennis tournaments held on the grounds of Shrubland Hall, Leamington Spa, England.
The cornerstone for the Statue of Liberty is laid on Bedloe's Island in New York Harbor.
A severe earthquake, magnitude 5.5, (intensity VII) occurs off the northeast Atlantic coast. The area affected extends from central Virginia to southern Maine, and west as far as Cleveland.
Sino–French War (for control of Tonkin) breaks out (continues to April 1885).
Sino–French War: Battle of Fuzhou: French Admiral Amédée Courbet's Far East Squadron virtually destroys China's Fujian Fleet.
Staten Island Academy is founded.
Medicine: The invention of local anaesthesia by Karl Koller was made public at a medical congress in Heidelberg, Germany
October ampampndash International Meridian Conference in Washington, D.C. fixes the Greenwich meridian as the world's prime meridian.
The United States Naval War College is established in Newport, Rhode Island.
The University of Wales, Bangor (UK) is founded.
Letitia Alice Walkington becomes the first woman to receive a degree from the Royal University of Ireland.
The Irish Gaelic Athletic Association is founded in Thurles, Ireland.
Timişoara is the first town of Europe with streets illuminated by electric light.
United States presidential election, 1884: Democrat Grover Cleveland defeats Republican James G. Blaine in a very close contest to win the first of his non-consecutive terms.
The Berlin Conference which regulates European colonisation and trade in Africa begins (ends February 26, 1885).

American Old West: Near Frisco, New Mexico, deputy sheriff Elfego Baca holds off a gang of 80 Texan cowboys who want to kill him for arresting cowboy Charles McCarthy (the cowboys were terrorizing the area's Hispanos and Baca was working against them).
Porfirio Díaz returns as President of Mexico, an office he will hold until 1911.
The Washington Monument is completed.
The World Cotton Centennial World's Fair opens in New Orleans, Louisiana.
The first successful appendectomy is performed by Dr. William W. Grant on Mary Gartside.
L.A. Thompson patents the roller coaster.
Edge Hill College opens in Liverpool
Troops loyal to the Mahdi Muhammad Ahmad conquer Khartoum.
King Léopold II of Belgium establishes the Congo Free State as a personal possession.
The play ''La vida alegre y muerte triste'' by dramatist José Echegaray opens.
The first Japanese arrive in Hawaii.
United States President Chester A. Arthur dedicates the Washington Monument.
A British executioner fails to hang John 'Babbacombe' Lee. Lee, sentenced for the murder of Emma Keyse, has his sentence commuted to life imprisonment.
The final act of the Berlin Conference regulates European colonization and trade in Africa.
February concludes without having a full moon.
MarchampampndashMay ampampndash The North-West Rebellion is suppressed in Canada.
A subsidiary of the American Bell Telephone Company, American Telephone and Telegraph (ATampT), is incorporated in New York.
Grover Cleveland succeeds Chester A. Arthur as President of the United States.
W. S. Gilbert and Arthur Sullivan's ''The Mikado'' opens at the Savoy Theatre.

''The Times'' reports that quotA lady well-known in literary and scientific circlesquot has been cremated by the Cremation Society in Woking, Surrey. Jeannette C. Pickersgill is the first person to be officially cremated in the United Kingdom.
The Prussian government, motivated by Otto von Bismarck, expels all ethnic Poles and Jews without German citizenship from Prussia in the Prussian deportations.
The Battle for Kushka triggers the Panjdeh Incident, which nearly gives rise to war between the British Empire and Russian Empire.
The United Kingdom establishes a protectorate over Bechuanaland.
The battle of Frog Lake, Alberta between the Cree and mounties.
Gottlieb Daimler is granted a German patent for his single-cylinder water-cooled engine design.
Luton Town Football Club are created by the merger of (Luton) Wanderers F.C. and Luton Excelsior F.C.
Final engagement of Sino–French War, with a French victory at Kép. China withdraws its forces from Tonkin.
A bill is signed in the New York State legislature forming the Niagara Falls State Park.
''Good Housekeeping'' Magazine goes on sale for the first time in the United States.
North-West Rebellion ampampndash Battle of Cut Knife: Cree and Assiniboine warriors win their largest victory over Canadian forces.
The Congo Free State is established by King Léopold II of Belgium.
May 12 ampndash Battle of Batoche: Canadian government forces inflict a decisive defeat on Métis rebels.
The first public train departs Swanage station on the newly built Swanage Railway in England.
The Statue of Liberty arrives in New York Harbor.
Robert Cecil, 3rd Marquess of Salisbury becomes British Prime Minister.
Randolph Churchill becomes Secretary of State for India.
Louis Pasteur successfully tests his vaccine against rabies. The patient is Joseph Meister, a boy who was bitten by a rabid dog.
Sarah E. Goode is the first female African-American to apply for and receive a patent, for the invention of the hideaway bed.
The Reservation at Niagara Falls opens, enabling access to all for free. Thomas V. Welch is the first Superintendent of the Park.
Professional football (soccer) is legalized in Britain.
Ulysses S. Grant, American Civil War general and the 18th President of the United States, dies at age 63.
Louis Riel's trial for treason begins in Regina.
S Andromedae, the only supernova seen in the Andromeda Galaxy so far by astronomers, and the first ever noted outside the Milky Way, is discovered.
The Rock Springs Massacre occurs in Rock Springs, Wyoming 150 white miners attack their Chinese coworkers, killing 28, wounding 15, and forcing several hundred more out of town.
Eastern Rumelia declares its union with Bulgaria, completing the Unification of Bulgaria.
Saint Thomas Academy is founded in Minnesota.
Arbroath 36-0 Bon Accord, the highest score ever in professional soccer.
A train wreck of the P.T. Barnum Circus kills giant elephant Jumbo.
The union of Eastern Rumelia with Bulgaria is proclaimed at Plovdiv.
A British force abolishes the Boer republic of Stellaland and adds it to British Bechuanaland.
The Georgia Institute of Technology is established in Atlanta, Georgia as the Georgia School of Technology.
November ampampndash The Third Burmese War begins.

Canadian Pacific Railway: In Craigellachie, British Columbia, construction ends on a railway extending across Canada. Prime Minister Sir John A. Macdonald considers the project to be vital to Canada due to the exponentially greater potential for military mobility.
November 28 ampndash Serbo-Bulgarian War: Serbia declares war against Bulgaria but is defeated in the Battle of Slivnitsa on November 17ampndashNovember 19.
Louis Riel, Canadian rebel leader of the Métis, is executed for high treason.
The U.S. Patent Office acknowledges this date as the day Dr Pepper is served for the very first time the exact date of Dr Pepper's invention is unknown.
72 Indian lawyers, academics and journalists gather in Bombay to form the Congress Party.
Burma is presented to Queen Victoria as a birthday gift, after the country is annexed into British India in November 1885.
A resolution is passed in the German Parliament, to condemn the Prussian deportations, the politically motivated mass expulsion of ethnic Poles and Jews from Prussia, initiated by Otto von Bismarck.
Modern field hockey is born with the formation of The Hockey Association in England.
Karl Benz patents the first successful gasoline-driven automobile, the Benz Patent Motorwagen (built in 1885).
The first train load of oranges leaves Los Angeles via the transcontinental railroad.
The Treaty of Bucharest ends the Serbo-Bulgarian War in the Balkans.
Anti-Chinese sentiments result in riots in Seattle, USA.
A law establishing the Kiel Canal is adopted.
Carrollton Massacre: 20 African Americans are killed in Mississippi.
Wilhelm Steinitz becomes first recognized World Chess Champion.
William Ewart Gladstone introduces the First Irish Home Rule Bill in the British Parliament it is defeated on June 8.
Easter occurs on the latest possible date (the next time in 1943).
A general strike begins in the United States, which escalates into the Haymarket Riot and eventually wins the eight-hour workday in the U.S.
Emil Berliner starts work that leads to the invention of the gramophone.
Pharmacist Dr. John Stith Pemberton invents a carbonated beverage that would be named ''Coca-Cola''.
Portugal and France agree to regulate the borders of their colonies in Guinea.
Motherwell Football Club was Founded.
''Santa Clara County v. Southern Pacific Railroad'': The U.S. Supreme Court rules that corporations have the same rights as living persons.
Pharmacist John Pemberton begins to advertise ''Coca-Cola'' (ad in the ''Atlanta Journal'').
U.S. President Grover Cleveland marries Frances Folsom in the White House, becoming the only president to wed in the executive mansion. She is 27 years his junior.
The centennial of the Stoughton Musical Society is celebrated.
The Mount Tarawera volcano erupts in New Zealand, resulting in the deaths of over 150 people and the destruction of the famous Pink and White Terraces.
King Ludwig II of Bavaria is captured.
A fire devastates much of Vancouver, British Columbia.
The Royal Holloway, University of London is opened by Queen Victoria in Surrey, United Kingdom.
Karl Benz officially unveils the Benz Patent Motorwagen .
Charles Hall files a patent for his process of turning aluminium oxide into molten aluminium.
Steve Brodie fakes a jump from the Brooklyn Bridge.
Robert Cecil, 3rd Marquess of Salisbury (Conservative Party (UK)) becomes Great Britain's 30th Prime Minister.
A massive hurricane demolishes the town of Indianola, Texas.
An earthquake of between 7.3 and 7.6 on the Richter Scale hits Charlestown, South Carolina, leaving 40,000 homeless.
Grasshopper Club Zurich is founded as first football club in the City of Zurich.
American Indian Wars: After almost 30 years of fighting, Apache leader Geronimo surrenders with his last band of warriors to General Nelson Miles at Skeleton Canyon in Arizona.
Bern Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works.
The first day of school begins in the newly founded Alhambra School District.
William Stanley, Jr. patents the first practical alternating current transformer device, the induction coil.
Spain abolishes slavery in Cuba.
In New York Harbor, U.S. President Grover Cleveland dedicates the Statue of Liberty.
November ampampndash extremely harsh Winter of 1886–1887 begins, killing tens of thousands of cattle on the Great Plains
In Pakistan one of the biggest schools in the country, Aitchison College, Lahore, was founded by Sir Charles Umpherston Aitchison
Heinrich Hertz verifies at the University of Karlsruhe the existence of the electromagnetic waves.
The ''Folies Bergère'' stages its first revue.
English adventurer Thomas Stevens concludes the first circumnavigation by bicycle in Yokohama, having set out on his penny-farthing from San Francisco in 1884.
Arsenal Football Club is founded.
Louis Pasteur's anti-rabies treatment is defended in the French Academy of Medicine by Dr. Joseph Grancher.
The United States Senate allows the Navy to lease Pearl Harbor as a naval base.
The Amateur Athletic Union (AAU) is formed.
Brisbane receives a daily rainfall of 465 millimetres ampampndash a record for any Australian capital city.
Battle of Dogali: Abyssinian troops defeat the Italians.
In a snowstorm at Fort Keogh, Montana, USA, the largest snowflakes on record are reported. They are 15ampnbspinches (38ampnbspcm) wide and 8ampnbspinches (20ampnbspcm) thick.
Construction of the foundations of the Eiffel Tower starts in Paris, France.
In Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania, the first Groundhog Day is observed.
The Interstate Commerce Act of 1887, as passed by the 49th United States Congress, is signed into law by President Grover Cleveland.
The Giuseppe Verdi opera ''Otello'' premieres at La Scala.
The Dawes Act, or the General Allotment Act, is enacted.
The French Riviera is hit by a large earthquake, killing around 2,000 along the coast of the Mediterranean Sea.
At the Sydney Cricket Ground, George Lohmann becomes the first bowler to take eight wickets in a Test innings.  The famous William Frawley was born.
Anne Sullivan begins teaching Helen Keller.
Gottlieb Daimler unveils his first automobile.
North Carolina State University is established as North Carolina College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts.
Chester Greenwood patents earmuffs.
Henry Cogswell College is established by Henry D. Cogswell.
Mumbai Fire Brigade is established.
Argonia, Kansas elects Susanna M. Salter as the first female mayor in the United States.
The Catholic University of America is founded on Easter Sunday.
Occidental College is founded.
Schnaebele incident ampndash French/German border incident nearly leads to war between the two countries.
An earthquake hits Sonora, Mexico.
''Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show'' opens in London.
The cornerstone of the new Stanford University, in northern California, is laid (the college opens in 1891).
Herman Hollerith receives a patent for his punched card calculator.
The Reinsurance Treaty is closed between Germany and Russia.
Minot, North Dakota is incorporated as a city.
The United Retail Federation is established in Brisbane.
Construction of the iron structure of the Eiffel Tower starts in Paris, France

King Kalākaua of Hawai'i is forced by anti-monarchists to sign the 'Bayonet Constitution', stripping the Hawaiian monarchy of much of its authority as well as disfranchising most native Hawaiians, all Asians and the poor.
Odense Boldklub, the Danish football team, is founded as the Odense Cricket Club.
Blackpool F.C. is created in England.
August ampampndash The earliest constituent of the U.S. National Institutes of Health is established at the Marine Hospital, Staten Island, as the Laboratory of Hygiene.

Hibernian F.C. of Scotland defeats Preston North End of England to win the quotChampionship of the Worldquot after the two teams win the Association football Cup competitions in their respective countries.
The Theatre Royal, Exeter, England, burns down, killing 186 people.
Start of the 1887 Yellow River flood in China, killing 900,000 to 2,000,000 people.
The British Empire takes over Balochistan.
Florida AampM University opens its doors in Tallahassee, Florida.
November
Results of the Michelson-Morley experiment are published, indicating that the speed of light is independent of motion.
Arthur Conan Doyle's detective character Sherlock Holmes makes his first appearance, in the novel ''A Study in Scarlet'' published in ''Beeton's Christmas Annual''.
The Associação Académica de Coimbra, the students' union of the University of Coimbra in Portugal, is founded.
Emile Berliner is granted a patent for his Gramophone.
Louis Lingg, sentenced to be hanged for his alleged role in the Haymarket Riot bomb, kills himself by dynamite.
August Spies, Albert Parsons, Adolph Fischer, George Engel, Michael Schwab, and Samuel Fielden are hanged for inciting riot and murder in the Haymarket Riot of May 4, 1886.
Bloody Sunday: Police clash with pro-Irish independence protesters.
International Bureau of Intellectual Property.
''Glenfiddich'' single malt Scotch whisky is first produced.
The 91-centimeter telescope is first used at Lick Observatory.

Blizzards (see: ''Schoolhouse Blizzard'') hit Dakota Territory, the states of Montana, Minnesota, Nebraska, Kansas, and Texas, leaving 235 dead, many of whom are children on their way home from school.
In Washington, DC, the National Geographic Society is founded.
In West Orange, New Jersey, Thomas Edison meets with Eadweard Muybridge, who proposes a scheme for sound film.
The Agriculture College of Utah, (later Utah State University) is founded in Logan, Utah.
Frederick III is crowned German Emperor.
The quotGreat Blizzard of '88quot begins along the eastern seaboard of the United States, shutting down commerce and killing more than 400.
Start of the Sikkim Expedition. A British military expedition to expel the Tibetans from northern Sikkim.
The very first Romani language operetta premieres in Moscow, Russia.
The Football League is formed.
Dorus Rijkers saves the 30-man crew of the ''Renown'', risking his own life.
The  Brighton Beach Hotel in Coney Island is moved 520 feet using six steam locomotives by Civil Engineer B.C. Miller to save it from ocean storms.
The Concertgebouw in Amsterdam is inaugurated.
The United States Congress establishes the Fort Belknap Indian Reservation.
Brazil abolishes the last remnants of slavery.
In Scotland, the Celtic F.C. plays its first official match winning 5–2 against Rangers F.C..
Hong Kong Peak Tram began operation.
June ampampndash Annie Besant organizes the London matchgirls strike of 1888.
The ''Kingdom of Sedang'' is formed in modern-day Vietnam.
''Casey at the Bat'' is published.
Wilhelm II is crowned German Emperor.
In Chicago, the Republican Convention opens at the Auditorium Building. Benjamin Harrison amp Levi Morton win the nominations for President and Vice President, respectively.
Handel's ''Israel in Egypt'' is recorded onto wax cylinder at The Crystal Palace, it being the earliest known recording of classical music.
The Marine Biological Association Laboratory opens on Plymouth Hoe, Devon, UK.

Frank Edward McGurrin, a court stenographer from Salt Lake City, Utah,  purportedly the only person using touch typing at the time, wins a decisive victory over Louis Traub in a typing contest held in Cincinnati, Ohio. This date can be called the birthday of the touch typing method that is widely used now.

The British Parliament passes an act that permits bicycles on the road, on condition that they are equipped with a bell that should be rung while on the carriageway. The law is eventually abolished in 1930.

Berta Benz arrives in Pforzheim, having driven {{convert|40|mi|km}} from Mannheim in a car manufactured by her husband Karl Benz, thus completing the first quotlong-distancequot drive in the history of the automobile.
The body of Martha Tabram is found, a possible murder victim of Jack the Ripper.
There is a mutiny at Dufile, India, and the Emin Pasha is imprisoned.
Mary Ann Nichols is murdered. She is considered the first of Jack the Ripper's victims.
George Eastman registers the trademark ''Kodak'', and receives a patent for his camera which uses roll film.

Charles Turner becomes the first cricket bowler to take 250 wickets in an English season ampndash a feat since accomplished only by Tom Richardson (twice), J.T. Hearne, Wilfred Rhodes (twice) and Tich Freeman (six times).
In London, the dead body of Annie Chapman is found. She is considered to be the second victim of Jack the Ripper.
In England, the first 6 Football League matches are played.
In London, the bodies of Elizabeth Stride and Catherine Eddowes are found. They are generally considered Jack the Ripper's third and fourth victims, respectively.
Sofia University officially opens, becoming the first university in liberated Bulgaria.
The Washington Monument officially opens to the general public.
Louis Le Prince films the first motion picture: ''Roundhay Garden Scene'' in Roundhay, Leeds, West Yorkshire, UK (followed by his movie ''Leeds Bridge'').

Seeking to extend Mahdist control over what is now southwestern Ethiopia, governor Khalil al-Khuzani is routed at the Battle of Guté Dili by an alliance of Shewan forces under ''Ras'' Gobana Dacche and Moroda Bekere, ruler of Leqa Naqamte. Only a handful, including Khalil, barely manage to flee the battle field.
St. Cuthbert's Society, University of Durham is founded after a general meeting, chaired by the Reverend Hastings Rashdall.
Birthday of Chandrasekhara Venkata Raman, Indian physicist and Nobel laureate, discoverer of Raman scattering.

In London, England, the dead body of Mary Jane Kelly is found. She is considered to be the fifth, and last, of Jack the Ripper's victims. A number of similar murders in England follow, but the police attribute them to copy-cat killers.
the first St V-parade by students in Brussels.
Delta Delta Delta was founded at Boston University.
Richard Wetherill and his brother-in-law discover the Indian ruins of Mesa Verde in southwestern Colorado.
During a bout of mental illness, Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh infamously cuts off the lower part of his own left ear.

An Act to Regulate Appointments in the Marine Hospital Service of the United States is signed by President Grover Cleveland. It establishes a Commissioned Corps of officers as a predecessor to the current U.S. Public Health Service Commissioned Corps.
Preston is declared the winner of the inaugural Football League in England.
Herman Hollerith receives a patent for his electric tabulating machine in the United States.
The ''Coca-Cola Company'', then known as the Pemberton Medicine Company, is originally incorporated in Atlanta, Georgia.
''Columbia Phonograph'' is formed in Washington, DC.
Crown Prince Rudolf of Austria and his mistress Baroness Mary Vetsera commit a double suicide (or a murder suicide) in the Mayerling hunting lodge.
The first issue of ''Glasgow University Magazine'' is published.
The Meiji Constitution of Japan is adopted the 1st Diet of Japan convenes in 1890.
President Grover Cleveland signs a bill admitting North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana and Washington as U.S. states.
Grover Cleveland, 22nd President of the United States (1885 ampndash 1889) is succeeded by Benjamin Harrison (1889–1893).
Yohannes IV is killed in the Battle of Metemma Sudanese forces, who had been almost defeated, rally and destroy the Ethiopian army.
The North Carolina Legislature issues a charter for the creation of Elon College.

A German naval force shells a village in Samoa, destroying some American property three American warships enter the Samoan harbor and prepare to fire on the three German warships found there. Before guns are fired, the 1889 Apia cyclone blows in and sinks all the ships, American and German. A compulsory armistice is called because of the lack of warships.
English football team Sheffield United F.C. formed at the Adelphi Hotel, Sheffield.
Claiming to be the Promised Messiah and Mahdi, Mirza Ghulam Ahmad founds the Ahmadiyya Muslim community in India.
The Eiffel Tower is inaugurated (opens May 6). At 300 m, the its height exceeds the previous tallest structure in the world by 130 m. Contemporary critics regard it as aesthetically displeasing.
Following a failed attempt at a coup, French defense minister Georges Boulanger is forced to flee the country.
The Hammarby Roddförening (later Hammarby Fotboll) is founded in Sweden.
At high noon in Oklahoma Territory, thousands rush to claim land in the Land Run of 1889. Within hours the cities of Oklahoma City and Guthrie are formed, with populations of at least 10,000.
Menelik II, Emperor of Ethiopia, signs a treaty of amity with Italy, giving Italy control over what will become Eritrea.
The Exposition Universelle opens in Paris with the Eiffel Tower as its entrance arch. The Galerie des machines, at 111 m, spans the longest interior space in the world at this time.
Johnstown Flood: The South Fork Dam collapses in western Pennsylvania, killing more than 2,200 people in and around Johnstown, Pennsylvania.
June ampampndash Vincent van Gogh paints ''Starry Night'' at Saint-Rémy-de-Provence.
The first long distance electric power transmission line in the United States is completed, running {{convert|14|mi|km}} between a generator at Willamette Falls and downtown Portland, Oregon.
The Great Seattle Fire ravages through the downtown area without any fatalities.
''The Wall Street Journal'' is established.
The Armagh rail disaster near Armagh in Ireland kills 78.
A Neapolitan baker named Raffaele Esposito invents the Pizza Margherita, named after the queen consort of Italy Margherita of Savoy. This is the forerunner of the modern pizza.
June 30 ampndash First Inter-Parliamentary Conference held.
The first issue of ''The Wall Street Journal'' is published.
International Workers Congresses of Paris open and establish the Second International.
Louise, Princess Royal of the United Kingdom, marries Alexander Duff, 1st Duke of Fife.
Mahdist War: Egyptian and British victory at the Battle of Toski.

At the Vienna Hofburg, the grand opening ceremony is held for the Imperial Natural History Museum ({{Lang-de|K.k. Naturhistorisches Hofmuseum}}), begun in 1871 from August 13 to the end of December, the museum counts 175,000 visitors.

September 15 ampndash London Dock Strike: Dockers strike for a minimum wage of sixpence an hour (quotThe dockers' tannerquot), which they eventually receive, a landmark in the development of New Unionism in Britain.

The Prevention of Cruelty to, and Protection of, Children Act, commonly known as the ''Children's Charter'', is passed in the United Kingdom for the first time it imposes criminal penalties to deter child abuse.
Official opening of Royal Mail Mount Pleasant Sorting Office in London.
August ampampndash The Jewish Settlement of Moisés Ville is founded in Argentina.
Albert Honoré Charles Grimaldi becomes Albert I, Prince of Monaco.
Civil War veteran Charles Jefferson Wright founds New York Military Academy with 75 students on {{convert|30|acre|m2}} of land in Cornwall, New York.
The ''Nintendo'' Koppai (Later ''Nintendo'' Company, Limited) is founded by Fusajiro Yamauchi to produce and market Hanafuda playing cards.
In Washington, DC, the first International Conference of American States begins.
The ''Moulin Rouge'' cabaret opens in Paris.
Sir Henry Parkes, Premier of New South Wales, delivers the Tenterfield Oration calling for the Federation of Australia.
November ampampndash The first free elections are held in Costa Rica.
North Dakota and South Dakota are admitted as the 39th and 40th U.S. states.
Montana is admitted as the 41st U.S. state.
Washington is admitted as the 42nd U.S. state.

Inspired by Jules Verne, pioneer woman journalist Nellie Bly (Elizabeth Cochrane) begins an attempt to beat travel around the world in less than 80 days (Bly finishes the journey in 72 days, 6 hours and 11 minutes).
Field Marshal Deodoro da Fonseca organizes a military coup which deposes Emperor Pedro II of Brazil and abolishes the Brazilian monarchy.
The Brazilian Royal Family is forced into exile in France.
The Empire of Brazil officially becomes a Federal Republic and Field Marshal Deodoro da Fonseca becomes its first president.
Argentina is the first country to recognize the abolition of the monarchy in Brazil.
Gustav Mahler's First Symphony premieres.
The first jukebox goes into operation at the Palais Royale Saloon in San Francisco.
Clemson University is founded in Clemson, South Carolina.
The Bayswater Railway Station (Victoria, Australia) officially opens.
Wofford and Furman play the first intercollegiate football game in the state of South Carolina.
The Spanish football team Recreativo de Huelva is formed (currently the oldest club in Spain).
1890 British Ultimatum: the United Kingdom demands Portugal withdraw its forces from the land between the Portuguese colonies of Mozambique and Angola (most of present-day Zimbabwe and Zambia)
The Sleeping Beauty (ballet) with music by Tchaikovsky is premiered at the Imperial Mariinsky Theatre in St Petersburg, Russia.
The United Mine Workers of America is founded.
Nellie Bly completes her round-the-world journey in 72 days.
Chicago is selected to host the Columbian Exposition
Léon Bourgeois succeeds Jean Antoine Ernest Constans as French Minister of the Interior.
The first football game in Ohio State history is played in Delaware, Ohio against Ohio Wesylan where Ohio State won 20–14.
The longest bridge in Britain, the Forth Bridge (8,296ampnbspft) in Scotland, is opened.
North Dakota State University is founded in Fargo, North Dakota.
Wilhelm II of Germany dismisses Otto von Bismarck.
A tornado strikes Louisville, Kentucky, killing 76 people and injuring 200.
Washington State University is founded in Pullman, Washington.
Commercial Bureau of the American Republics
The first ever ''official'' English County Championship cricket match begins in Bristol Yorkshire beats Gloucestershire by 8 wickets.
The 5-story skylight Arcade opens in Cleveland, Ohio.

The United States Census Bureau begins using Herman Hollerith's tabulating machine to tabulate census returns using punched card input, a landmark in the history of computing hardware. Hollerith's company eventually becomes IBM.
''The Picture of Dorian Gray'' by Oscar Wilde published by Philadelphia-based ''Lippincott's Monthly Magazine''.
Canadian-born boxer George Dixon defeats the British bantamweight champion in London, giving him claim to be the first black world champion in any sport.
July ampampndash Politics of Japan: In the first general election for the House of Representatives of Japan, c. 5% of the adult male population elect a lower house of the Diet of Japan.
Heligoland-Zanzibar Treaty is signed by Great Britain and Germany.
The Sherman Antitrust Act and Sherman Silver Purchase Act become United States law.
Idaho is admitted as the 43rd U.S. state.
Wyoming is admitted as the 44th U.S. state.
In Minnesota, storms result in the Sea Wing disaster on Lake Pepin killing 98.
In Buenos Aires, the ''Revolución del Parque'' takes place, forcing President Juárez Celman's resignation.
Dutch artist Vincent van Gogh dies near Paris, France, after shooting himself.
At Auburn Prison in New York, William Kemmler becomes the first person to be executed in the electric chair.
Treaty of London: Portugal and the United Kingdom define the borders of the Portuguese colonies of Mozambique and Angola.
Weather Bureau (within Department of Agriculture).
In Washington, D.C., the Daughters of the American Revolution is founded.
The Delta Chi Fraternity is founded by 11 law students at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York.
Edward King, Anglican bishop of Lincoln, is convicted of using ritualistic practices.
King William III of the Netherlands dies without a male heir, and his daughter Princess Wilhelmina becomes Queen, causing Luxembourg (who required a male heir) to declare independence.
The Meiji Constitution goes into effect in Japan and the first Diet convenes.
In West Point, New York, the United States Navy defeats the United States Army 24–0 in the first Army–Navy Game.
November ampampndash Scotland Yard, headquarters of the Metropolitan Police Service, moves to a building on London's Victoria Embankment, as the New Scotland Yard.

Wounded Knee Massacre: At Wounded Knee, South Dakota, a Native American camp, the U.S. 7th Cavalry Regiment tries to disperse the non-violent quotGhost-Dancequot which was promised to usher in a new era of power and freedom to Native Americans but was feared as a potential rallying tool for violent rebellion by some in the U.S. government.  Shooting begins, and 153 Lakota Sioux and 25 troops are killed about 150 flee the scene.
Paying of old age pensions begins in Germany.
The Chilean Civil War breaks out.
Jim Hogg becomes the first native Texan to be governor of that state.
Liliuokalani is proclaimed Queen of Hawaii.
The Portuguese republican revolution breaks out in the northern city of Porto.

In the FA Cup Quarter Final, a goal is deliberately stopped by handball on the goal line. An Indirect free kick is awarded, since the Penalty kick was proposed that year but not implemented. This event probably changes public opinion on the penalty kick, which was seen as 'an Irishman's motion' before (see William McCrum).
AIK is founded.
Springhill, Nova Scotia suffers a serious mining disaster.
The International Copyright Act of 1891 is passed by the Fifty-first United States Congress.
March 12 ampndash A powerful storm off England's south coast sinks 14 ships.
In New Orleans, a lynch mob storms the Old Parish Prison and lynches 11 Italians arrested but found innocent of the murder of Police Chief David Hennessy.
Jesse W. Reno patents the first escalator at Coney Beach.
The Wrigley Company is founded in Chicago.
Census in the United Kingdom. 15.6 million people live in cities of 20,000 or more in England and Wales. Cities of 20,000 or more account for 54% of the total English population.
May ampampndash Mirza Ghulam Ahmad claims to be the Promised Messiah (The second coming of Jesus) and the Mahdi awaited in Islam.
Troops fire on a workers' May Day demonstration in support of the 8-hour workday in Fourmies, France, killing 9 and wounding 30.
The first ''Fascio dei lavoratori'' (Workers League) is founded by Giuseppe De Felice Giuffrida in Catania, (Sicily).
The Music Hall in New York (now known as Carnegie Hall) has its grand opening and first public performance, with maestro Peter Ilyich Tchaikovsky as the guest conductor.
Otsu Incident: Tsesarevich Nikolay Alexandrovich (the future Czar Nicholas II) of Russia survives an assassination attempt while visiting Japan.
Pope Leo XIII issues the encyclical ''Rerum Novarum'', resulting in the creation of many Christian Democrat Parties throughout Europe.
Thomas Alva Edison's prototype kinetoscope is first displayed at Edison's Laboratory, for a convention of the National Federation of Women's Clubs.

.S. (May 19 O.S.) ampndash In the Kuperovskaya district of Vladivostok, a grand ceremonial inauguration of construction work on the Trans-Siberian Railway is carried out by the Tsesarevich Nikolay Alexandrovich and a religious service held.
The Johnstown Inclined Plane opens in Johnstown, Pennsylvania.
John Abbott becomes Canada's third prime minister.
First long-distance transmission of alternating current by the Ames power plant near Telluride, Colorado, by Lucien and Paul Nunn.
July 30 ampampndash The Springboks rugby union team of South Africa play their first international test match against the Lions team of the British Isles and win by 4-0.
France and Russia conclude a defensive alliance.
The first penalty kick is awarded in a football (soccer) match John Heath scores it for the Wolverhampton Wanderers.
The C.A. Peñarol is founded in Montevideo under the name of the CURCC (Central Uruguay Railway Cricket Club).

October ampampndash Eugène Dubois finds the first fragmentary bones of ''Pithecanthropus erectus'' (later redesignated ''Homo erectus''), or 'Java Man', at Trinil on the Solo River.ampamp{{cite book|first=Sean B.|last=Carroll|title=Remarkable Creatures: Epic Adventures in the Search for the Origin of Species|location=London|publisher=Quercus|year=2009|isbn=978-1-84916-072-8|pages=90–91}}ampamp
In California, Stanford University opens its doors.
An 8.0 earthquake strikes the village of Utsuzumi in rural Gifu, Japan, killing over 7,000 across the region and creating a 3-meter-tall surface fault that is still visible.
The Jindandao Incident breaks out in the Juu Uda League, Inner Mongolia, massacred tens of thousands of Mongols before being suppressed by government troops in late December.
The Brazilian Old Republic Constitution was promulgated.
The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers was organized.
Asteroid 323 Brucia becomes the first asteroid discovered using photography.
Ellis Island begins accommodating immigrants to the United States.
James Naismith publishes the rules for basketball.
At the YMCA in Springfield, Massachusetts, the first official basketball game is played.
Pennsauken Township, New Jersey is incorporated.
Rudolf Diesel applies for a patent on his compression ignition engine (the Diesel engine).
Theodoros Deligiannis ends his term as Prime Minister of Greece and Konstantinos Konstantopoulos takes office.
Ernest Louis, a grandson of Queen Victoria, becomes Grand Duke of Hesse and the Rhine on the death of his father, Grand Duke Louis IV.
The Liverpool Football Club is founded by John Houlding, the owner of Anfield. Houlding decides to form his own team after Everton leaves Anfield in an argument over rent.
The world's first fingerprinting bureau is formally opened by the Buenos Aires Chief of Police it had been operating unofficially since the previous year.
April ampampndash The Johnson County War breaks out between small farmers and large ranchers in Wyoming.
The city of Maebashi is founded by the samurai Makuba Kawai.
The General Electric Company is established through the merger of the Thomson-Houston Company and the Edison General Electric Company.
Redondo Beach, California, USA is founded.
The Cook Islands issue their first postage stamps.
Battle of Yemoja River: British troops defeat Ijebu infantry in modern-day Nigeria, using a maxim gun.
The British conquest of Ijebu-Ode marks a major extension of colonial power into the Nigerian interior.
Prince George (later George V) becomes Duke of York.
In San Francisco, California, John Muir organizes the Sierra Club.
Abercrombie amp Fitch is established by David T. Abercrombie.
Homer Plessy (who is black) is arrested for sitting on the whites-only car in Louisiana, leading to the landmark ''Plessy v. Ferguson'' court case.
The Limelight Department, later one of the world's first film studios, is officially established in Melbourne, Australia.
The Homestead Strike begins in Homestead, Pennsylvania, culminating in a battle between striking workers and private security agents on July 6.
Samoa: Samoa changes its time zone to being 3 hours behind California, such that it crosses the international date line and July 4 occurs twice.
July 18 ampndash British general election: The Unionist government loses its majority.
Dr. Jose Rizal, Filipino writer, philosopher, and political activist is arrested by Spanish authorities in connection with La Liga Filipina.
Homestead Strike: The arrival of a force of 300 Pinkerton detectives from New York and Chicago results in a fight in which about 10 men are killed.
The Great Fire of 1892 devastates the city of St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador.
A hidden lake bursts out of a glacier on the side of Mont Blanc, flooding the valley below and killing around 200 villagers and holidaymakers in Saint-Gervais-les-Bains.
United International Bureau for the Protection of Intellectual Property (UIBPIP or BIRPI).
The father and stepmother of Lizzie Borden are found murdered in their Fall River, Massachusetts home.
Thomas Edison receives a patent for a two-way telegraph.
William Ewart Gladstone assumes British premiership at head of Liberal government, with Irish Nationalist Party support.
The Nottingham Forest Football Club plays their first league match, a 2–2 draw with Everton FC.
Sergei Witte replaces Ivan Vyshnegradsky as Russian finance minister.
The University of Chicago holds its first classes.
The Dalton Gang, attempting to rob 2 banks in Coffeyville, Kansas, is shot by the townspeople only Emmett Dalton, with 23 wounds, survives, to spend 14 years in prison.
Master criminal Adam Worth is captured in Liège, Belgium during an attempted robbery of a money delivery cart.
To mark the 400th anniversary Columbus Day holiday, the quotPledge of Allegiancequot is first recited in unison by students in U.S. public schools.
Sir Arthur Conan Doyle publishes ''The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes''.
U.S. presidential election, 1892: Grover Cleveland is elected over Benjamin Harrison and James B. Weaver to win the second of his non-consecutive terms.
An anarchist bomb kills six in a police station in Avenue de l'Opera, Paris.
The four-day New Orleans General Strike begins.
French troops occupy Abomey, capital of the kingdom of Dahomey.
John Thompson becomes Canada's fourth prime minister.
''The Nutcracker'' ballet with music by Tchaikovsky is premiered at the Imperial Mariinsky Theatre in St Petersburg, Russia.
The Newcastle East End F.C. is renamed Newcastle United F.C., following the demise of the Newcastle West End F.C. and East End's move to St James' Park, formerly West End's home.
Webb C. Ball introduces railroad chronometers, which become the general railroad timepiece standards in North America.
The Independent Labour Party of the UK has its first meeting.
The U.S. Marines intervene in Hawaii, resulting in overthrow of the government of Queen Liliuokalani of Hawaii.
The Cherry Sisters first perform in Marion, Iowa.
Thomas A. Edison finishes construction of the first motion picture studio in West Orange, New Jersey.
The SS ''Naronic'' is believed to have sunk due to a storm.
Rudolf Diesel receives a patent for the diesel engine.
American University is established by an Act of Congress in Washington, D.C.
Benjamin Harrison is succeeded by Grover Cleveland, as President of the United States.
Côte d'Ivoire becomes a French colony.
In Belgium, Adam Worth is sentenced to 7 years for robbery (he is released in 1897).
The rank of Chief Petty Officer is established in the United States Navy.
The first recorded college basketball game occurs in Beaver Falls, Pennsylvania between the Geneva College Covenanters and the New Brighton YMCA.
Riots of Mons during the Belgian general strike of 1893, The day after, Belgian parliament approved Universal suffrage.
Alpha Xi Delta founded
May ampampndash The Free Presbyterian Church of Scotland is formed.
The 1893 World's Fair, also known as the World's Columbian Exposition, opens to the public in Chicago, USA. The first United States commemorative postage stamps are issued for the Exposition.
Panic of 1893: A crash on the New York Stock Exchange starts a depression.
Edison's 1½ inch system of Kinetoscope is first demonstrated in public at the Brooklyn Institute.
The United States Supreme Court legally declares the tomato to be a vegetable.
Prince George, Duke of York (later George V) marries Mary of Teck.
Gandhi commits his first act of civil disobedience in India.
Gold is found in Kalgoorlie, Western Australia.
The Wengernalpbahn railway in Wengen, Switzerland (Canton of Bern) is opened.
Lizzie Borden acquitted of murdering her parents.
The flagship ''Victoria'' of the British Mediterranean Fleet collides with ''Camperdown'' and sinks in 10 minutes Vice-admiral Sir George Tryon goes down with his ship.
U.S. President Grover Cleveland is operated on in secret.
The small town of Pomeroy, Iowa is nearly destroyed by a tornado 71 people are killed and 200 injured.
Kokichi Mikimoto, in Japan, develops the method to seed and grow cultured pearls.
Frederick Jackson Turner gives a lecture titled ampquotThe Significance of the Frontier in American Historyampquot before the American Historical Association in Chicago.
The Dundee FC, a Scottish football club, is formed.
Ibadan area became a British Protectorate after a treaty signed by Fijabi, the Baale of Ibadan with the British acting Governor of Lagos, George C. Denton.
The Sea Islands Hurricane hits Savannah, Charleston, and the Sea Islands, killing 1,000–2,000.
The Genoa Cricket ampamp Athletic Club, the oldest Italian football club, is formed.
Under the pressure of a general strike, the Belgian Federal Parliament accepts a proposal to accept general multiple suffrage.
The World Parliament of Religions in Chicago opens its first meeting.
Standing ovation to Hindu monk Swami Vivekanda for his address in Response to the welcome at the World Parliament of Religions in Chicago.
Swami Vivekananda delivers an inspiring speech on his paper at the World Parliament of Religions in Chicago.
New Zealand becomes the first country in the world to grant women the right to vote.
The Russian ironclad ''Rusalka'' disappears in a storm en route from Tallinn to Helsinki her hulk is eventually discovered in July 2003, off Helsinki.
Brothers Charles and Frank Duryea drive the first gasoline-powered motorcar in America on public roads in Springfield, Massachusetts.
The Bahá'í Faith is first publicly mentioned in the United States at the World Parliament of Religions in Chicago.
The World Parliament of Religions holds its closing meeting in Chicago.
The Portuguese sports club Futebol Clube do Porto is founded.
The first car number plates appear in Paris, France.
The Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization (IMRO) is founded by the Bulgarians in the town of Thessaloniki.Its aim was to libarate the region of Macedonia from the Ottoman Turks.
The 1893 World's Fair, also known as the World's Columbian Exposition, closes.
November ampampndash In the United Kingdom, the Local Government Act 1894 is read for the second time in the House of Commons.
Colorado women are granted the right to vote.
The FC Basel Club is founded.
Plural voting is abolished in New South Wales.
Antonín Dvořák's Symphony No. 9 quotFrom the New Worldquot receives its premiere at Carnegie Hall, New York City.
December
Carl Anton Larsen becomes the first man to ski in Antarctica.

Arthur Conan Doyle surprises the reading public by revealing in the story ''The Adventure of the Final Problem'', published in this month's ''Strand Magazine'', that his character Sherlock Holmes had apparently died at the Reichenbach Falls on May 4, 1891.
A military alliance is established between the French Third Republic and the Russian Empire.
William Kennedy Dickson receives a patent for motion picture film.
New England Telephone and Telegraph installs the first battery-operated telephone switchboard in Lexington, Massachusetts.
French anarchist Émile Henry set off a bomb in a Parisian cafe, killing one person and wounding twenty.
February 12 The bark the 'Elisabeth Rickmers' of Bremerhaven, is wrecked at Haurvig, Denmark, fortunately, all crew and passengers are saved.
At 04:51 GMT, French anarchist Martial Bourdin attempts to destroy the Royal Greenwich Observatory, London, United Kingdom with a bomb.
For the first time, ''Coca-Cola'' is sold in bottles.
A syzygy of planets occurs as Mercury transits the Sun as seen from Venus, and Mercury and Venus both transit the Sun as seen from Saturn. But no two of the transits are simultaneous.
Coxey's Army, the first significant American protest march, departs from Massillon, Ohio for Washington
Manchester City Football Club is formed.
A bituminous coal miners' strike closes mines across the central United States.
May ampampndash The bubonic plague breaks out in the Tai Ping Shan area of Hong Kong (by the end of the year, the death toll is 2,552 people).
Coxey's Army arrives in Washington Coxey is arrested
The May Day Riots of 1894 break out in Cleveland, Ohio.
Pullman Strike: Three thousand Pullman Palace Car Company factory workers go on a quotwildcatquot (without union approval) strike in Illinois.
A meteor shower is seen in Southern France.
Blackpool Tower is opened in Blackpool, Lancashire, England.
The Manchester Ship Canal and Docks are opened by Queen Victoria.
Dahomey becomes a French colony.
The International Olympic Committee is founded at the Sorbonne, Paris, at the initiative of Baron Pierre de Coubertin.
Sadi Carnot, president of France, is assassinated.
The Tower Bridge in London opens for traffic.
July ampampndash A fire at the site of the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago destroys most of the remaining buildings.
The Republic of Hawaii is proclaimed by Sanford B. Dole.
FC La Chaux-de-Fonds founded.

War is declared between the Qing Empire of China and the Empire of Japan, over their rival claims of influence on their common ally, the Joseon Dynasty of Korea. The event marks the start of the first Sino-Japanese War.
Sante Geronimo Caserio is executed for the assassination of Marie François Sadi Carnot.
Great Hinckley Fire: A forest fire in Hinckley, Minnesota kills more than 450 people.
In New York City, 12,000 tailors strike against sweatshop working conditions.
The Owl Club of Cape Town, South Africa has its first formal meeting.
Dreyfus affair: French Army officer Alfred Dreyfus is arrested for spying.
Domenico Menegatti obtains a patent for a procedure to be applied in producing pandoro industrially.
Russian Tsar Alexander III is succeeded by his son Nicholas II.
Major Republican landslide in the United States House of Representatives elections, 1894, which set the stage for the decisive Election of 1896.
The Masonic Grand Lodge de France is founded, splitting from the larger and older Grand Orient de France.
Women in South Australia become the first in Australia to gain the right to vote and to be elected to Parliament.
Mackenzie Bowell becomes Canada's fifth prime minister.
Dreyfus Affair: French Army officer Alfred Dreyfus is convicted of treason.
Dreyfus Affair: French officer Alfred Dreyfus is stripped of his army rank and sentenced to life imprisonment on Devil's Island.
Félix Faure was elected President of French Republic after the resignation of Jean Casimir-Perier.
The National Trust is founded in Britain by Octavia Hill, Robert Hunter and Canon Hardwicke Rawnsley.
Mintonette, later known as volleyball, is created by William G. Morgan at Holyoke, Massachusetts.
The lowest ever UK temperature of {{convert|-27.2|°C|°F|abbr=on}} is recorded at Braemar in Aberdeenshire. This record is equalled in 1982 and again in 1995.
Oscar Wilde's last play ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' is first shown at St. James' Theatre in London.

Venezuela Crisis of 1895: President Grover Cleveland signs into law a bill resulting from the proposition of House Resolution 252 by William Lindsay Scruggs and Congressman Leonidas Livingston to the third session of the 53rd Congress of the United States of America. The bill recommends Venezuela and Great Britain settle their dispute by arbitration.
William L. Wilson is appointed United States Postmaster General.
In Munich, bicyclists have to pass a test and display license plates.
Japanese troops capture Liaoyang and land in Taiwan.
in County Tipperary, Ireland, Bridget Cleary is killed by her husband, believing her to be a fairy changeling.
Rudolf Diesel patents the Diesel engine in Germany.
Oscar Wilde is arrested after losing a libel case against the Marquess of Queensberry.
A major earthquake severely damages Ljubljana, Slovenia.
The town of Sturgeon Falls, Ontario, is incorporated.
Gongche Shangshu movement: 603 candidates sign a 10,000-word petition against the Treaty of Shimonoseki.
Dundela Football, Sports amp Association Club were formed
Gongche Shangshu movement: Thousands of Beijing scholars and citizens protest against the Treaty of Shimonoseki.
Anti-Japanese officials led by Tang Ching-sung in Taiwan declare independence from the Qing Dynasty, forming the short-lived Republic of Formosa.
Oscar Wilde is convicted of quotsodomy and gross indecencyquot and is sentenced to serve 2 years in prison at Reading.
''In re Debs'': The Supreme Court of the United States decides that the federal government has the right to regulate interstate commerce, legalizing the military suppression of the Pullman Strike.
The union of Nicaragua, Honduras and El Salvador begins (ends in 1898).
The Court of Private Land Claims rules that James Reavis's claim to Barony of Arizona is ampquotwholly fictitious and fraudulentampquot.
Night of July 10ampampndashJuly 11 ampampndash The Doukhobors' pacifist protests culminate in the ampquotBurning of the assampquot in their villages in the South Caucasus.
Archie MacLaren scores County Championship cricket record innings of 424 for Lancashire against Somerset at Taunton.
The Basque Nationalist Party (Euzko Alderdi Jeltzalea-Partido Nacionalista Vasco) was founded by Basque nationalist leader Sabino Arana.
American frontier murderer and outlaw John Wesley Hardin is killed by an off-duty policeman in a saloon in El Paso, Texas.
The Northern Rugby Football Union (now ''Rugby Football League'') is formed at a meeting  of 21 rugby clubs in the George Hotel, Huddersfield, England.
The first professional American football game is played, in Latrobe, Pennsylvania, between the Latrobe YMCA and the Jeannette Athletic Club (Latrobe wins 12–0).
The first game of what would become known as rugby league football is played, in England, starting the 1895–96 Northern Rugby Football Union season.

Booker T. Washington delivers the Atlanta Compromise speech.ampamp{{cite book|last=Gottheimer|first=Josh|coauthors=Bill Clinton, and Mary Frances Berry|year=2004|title=Ripples of Hope: Great American Civil Rights Speeches|page=128}}ampamp
October ampampndash Rudyard Kipling publishes the story ''Mowgli Leaves the Jungle Forever'' in ''The Cosmopolitan'' illustrated magazine (price 10 cents).
French troops capture Antananarivo in Madagascar.

The Eulmi Incident: Empress Myeongseong of Korea, is killed at her private residence within Gyeongbokgung Palace. Japanese agents under Miura Goro attack the Korean Royal Guard.  Her son Sunjong accuses General Woo Beom-seon.  Miura Goro is recalled to Japan, and tried along with 55 other men all were acquitted for lack of evidence.
A train wreck occurs at Montparnasse Station in Paris.
The city of Tainan, last stronghold of the Republic of Formosa, capitulates to the forces of the Empire of Japan, ending the short-lived republic and beginning the Japanese rule era.
A major earthquake occurs in the New Madrid Seismic Zone, the last to date.
George B. Selden is granted the first U.S. patent for an automobile.
Wilhelm Röntgen discovers a type of radiation later known as X-rays.
Oscar Hammerstein opens the Olympia Theatre, the first theatre to be built in NYC's Times Square district.
At the Swedish-Norwegian Club in Paris, Alfred Nobel signs his last will and testament, setting aside his estate to establish the Nobel Prize after his death.
December ampampndash 3,000 Armenians are burned alive in Urfa by Ottoman troops.
A corps of 2,350 Italian troops, mostly Ascari, are crushed by 30,000 Abyssian troops at Amba Alagi.
George Washington Vanderbilt II officially opens his quotBiltmore Housequot estate on Christmas Eve, inviting his family to celebrate his new home in Asheville, NC.
Kingstown Lifeboat Disaster- 15 lifeboat crew are lost when their lifeboat capsizes while trying to rescue the crew of the SS Palme off Kingstown, now Dún Laoighaire, near Dublin, Ireland.
Auguste and Louis Lumière display their first moving picture film in Paris.
Utah is admitted as the 45th U.S. state.
An Austrian newspaper reports that Wilhelm Röntgen has discovered a type of radiation later known as X-rays.
Fannie Farmer published her first cookbook.
H.L. Smith takes the first X-ray photograph.
The X-ray machine is exhibited for the first time.

Walter Arnold, of East Peckham, Kent, England, is fined 1 shilling for speeding at {{convert|8|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, thus exceeding the contemporary speed limit of {{convert|2|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. The first speeding fine.
The opera ''La bohème'' premieres in Turin, Italy.
International Association of Bridge and Structural Iron Workers was established in  Pittsburgh
Oscar Wilde's play quotSalomé'' premieres in Paris.
Battle of Adwa: Ethiopia defends its independence from Italy.
Responding to national outrage at the defeat at Adwa, Italian Prime Minister Francesco Crispi resigns.
The New York State Legislature passes the Raines Law, restricting Sunday alcoholic beverage sales to hotels.
The first edition of the Italian sports newspaper ''La Gazzetta dello Sport'' is published.
The first known women's basketball game between two colleges was played between Stanford and California.
The opening ceremonies of the 1896 Summer Olympics, the first modern Olympic Games, are held in Athens.
The National Farm School (later Delaware Valley College) is chartered in Doylestown, PA.
Cricket: Against Warwickshire, Yorkshire sets a still-standing County Championship record when they accumulate an innings total of 887.
''Plessy v. Ferguson'': The U.S. Supreme Court introduces the quotseparate but equalquot doctrine and upholds segregation.
Charles Dow publishes the first edition of the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

The costliest and third deadliest tornado in U.S. history levels a mile wide swath of downtown St. Louis, Missouri, incurring $2.9 billion (1997 USD) in normalized damages, killing more than 255 and injuring over 1,000 people.
The Ford Quadricycle, the first Ford vehicle ever developed, is completed, eventually leading Henry Ford to build the empire that quotput America on wheelsquot.
J.T. Hearne sets a record for the earliest date of taking 100 wickets. It is equalled by Charlie Parker in 1931.
An earthquake and tsunami in Sanriku, Japan, kills 27,000.
Liberal leader Wilfred Laurier defeats Charles Tupper during Canadian federal elections for the 8th Canadian Parliament, and becomes the first francophone Prime Minister of Canada.
William Jennings Bryan delivers his Cross of gold speech at the Democratic National Convention, which nominates him for President of the United States.
Wilfrid Laurier becomes Canada's seventh prime minister and the first French-speaker to hold that office.
In Washington, D.C. in response to a quotcall to conferquot issued by Josephine St. Pierre Ruffin to all women of color, the National Association of Colored Women's Clubs is organized.
International Socialist Workers and Trade Union Congress opens in London.
A causeway is opened between the islands of Saaremaa and Muhu in Estonia.

Shortly after 6:30 pm, at a crossing just west of Atlantic City, New Jersey, two trains collide, crushing five loaded passenger coaches, killing fifty and seriously injuring approximately sixty, in the 1896 Atlantic City rail crash.
August ampampndash An extraordinary heat wave affects the northeastern United States.
Skookum Jim Mason, George Carmack and Dawson Charlie discover gold in the Klondike.
Bridget Driscoll is run over by a Benz car in the grounds of The Crystal Palace, London, the world's first motoring fatality.
The shortest war in recorded history, the Anglo-Zanzibar War, starts at 9 in the morning and lasts for 45 minutes of shelling.
The Crash at Crush train wreck stunt is held in Texas.
Queen Victoria surpasses her grandfather King George III as the longest reigning monarch in British history.
Augusta, KY: The Augusta High School cornerstone is laid, marking the end of the Augusta Methodist College.
U.S. presidential election, 1896: Republican William McKinley defeats William Jennings Bryan.
A large carcass, later postulated to be the remains of a gigantic octopus, is found washed ashore near St. Augustine, Florida.
