The Udinese Calcio is founded.
The premiere of Alfred Jarry's absurdist play ''Ubu Roi'' in Paris causes a near-riot.
The Glasgow Subway, the third-oldest underground metro system in the world, opens.
John Philip Sousa composes his magnum opus, the ''Stars and Stripes Forever'', on Christmas Day.
Jose Rizal, Filipino scholar and poet, is executed by Spanish authorities in the Philippines.
The International Alpha Omicron Pi Sorority is founded.
A British force is ambushed by Chief Ologbosere, son-in-law of the Oba of Benin. This leads to a punitive expedition against Benin.

Elva Zona Heaster is found dead in Greenbrier County, West Virginia. The resulting murder trial of her husband is perhaps the only case in United States history where the testimony of a ghost helped secure a conviction.
Freedom of religion is proclaimed in Madagascar.
Benin is put to the torch by the Punitive Expedition.
Foundation of Cekan Mekenroff 1897 Bratislava Slovakia.
The Sigma Pi Fraternity is founded.
William McKinley succeeds Grover Cleveland as President of the United States.
San Diego State University is founded.
Vienna Secession movement founded.
The ''Ordinance of April 5,'' equalizing German and Czech in Bohemia, is signed in Austria-Hungary (see Count Kasimir Felix Badeni).
The Aurora, Texas UFO incident.
The first ever Challenge Cup final is played at Headingley.
Grant's Tomb is dedicated in New York.
The Tennessee Centennial Exposition opens in Nashville, for 6 months, illuminated by many electric lights.
The Snaefell Mining Disaster occurs in the Isle of Man.
The patent for an Exhaust muffler for engines was awarded to Milton and Marshall Reeves of Columbus, Indiana.

Guglielmo Marconi sends the first ever wireless communication over open sea when the message quotAre you readyquot is transmitted across the Bristol Channel from Lavernock Point in South Wales to Flat Holm Island, a distance of {{convert|3.7|mi|km}}.
Twenty-two years after the start of construction, Teatro Massimo opens in Palermo, the largest opera theatre in Italy and the third largest in Europe.
Oscar Wilde is released from prison.
''Dracula'', a novel by Irish author Bram Stoker, is published.
American miners begin a strike, which successfully establishes the United Mine Workers Union and brings about the 8-hour work day to mines.
Mark Twain, responding to rumors that he is dead, is quoted by the ''New York Journal'' as saying, quotThe report of my death was an exaggeration.quot

The world's first Fingerprint Bureau opens in Calcutta (now Kolkata), India, after the Council of the Governor General approves a committee report that fingerprints should be used for classification of criminal records.
Queen Victoria celebrates her Diamond Jubilee.

British colonial officers Rand and Ayerst in Pune, Maharashtra, India are assassinated on their way back from a Government house party celebrating the diamond jubilee coronation anniversary of Queen Victoria, by the Chapekar brothers and Ranade, who are later caught and hanged. Considered the first martyrs to the cause of India's freedom from Britain. The film 22 June 1897 is based on the incident.
Fort Erie Racetrack in Fort Erie, Ontario, opens.  The first race is won by Ellesmere, guided home by Sullivan.
S. A. Andrée's Arctic balloon expedition of 1897 begins. The ill-fated expedition to fly over the Arctic results in the death of the entire team within months.
The Klondike Gold Rush begins when the first successful prospectors arrive in Seattle.
Writer Jack London sails to join the Klondike Gold Rush where he will write his first successful stories.
Mount Saint Elias, the second highest peak in the United States and Canada, is first ascended.
The Oldsmobile is founded in Lansing, MI by Ransom E. Olds.
The First Zionist Congress convenes in Basel, Switzerland.
The Boston subway opens, becoming the first underground metro in North America.
Lattimer Massacre: A sheriff's posse kills more than 19 unarmed immigrant miners in Pennsylvania.
After months of searching, generals of Menelik II of Ethiopia capture Gaki Sherocho, the last king of Kaffa, bringing an end to that ancient kingdom.

The Battle of Saragarhi: Twenty-one Sikhs of the 36th Sikh of the Sikh Regiment of British India, defend an army post against 10,000 Afghan and Orakzai tribesmen. The battle occurs in the North-West Frontier Province Afghanistan, now a part of Pakistan, which then formed part of British India.
Greece and Turkey sign a peace treaty to end the Greco-Turkish War.
The first issue of the radical paper ''Tocsin'' is published.
After a long siege, Brazilian government troops take Canudos in north Brazil, crushing Antônio Conselheiro and his followers.
Ethiopia uses the tricolor flag: green is for the land, yellow for gold, and red is symbolic of strength and the blood shed.
The USS ''Baltimore'' (Cruiser # 3, later CM-1) is recommissioned, since 1890, for several months of duty in the Hawaiian Islands.
The City of Belo Horizonte, Brazil is created. The construction of the second Brazilian Planned City is completed successfully, an immigration of 1,000,000 people is estimated.
The HMS Canopus (1898), a pre-Dreadnought battleship of the Royal Navy, is launched at Portsmouth, England (will be deployed widely in World War I).
The Kappa Delta Sorority is founded.
The Juventus F.C. football club is founded.
Spain grants Puerto Rico autonomy.
The first issue of the feminist newspaper ''La Fronde'' is published by Marguerite Durand.
The play ''Cyrano de Bergerac'', by Edmond Rostand, premieres in Paris.
Natal annexes Zululand.

New York City annexes land from surrounding counties, creating the City of Greater New York. The city is geographically divided into five boroughs: Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, The Bronx, and Staten Island.
Emile Zola publishes ''J'Accuse'' a letter accusing the French government of anti-Semitism and wrongfully placing Alfred Dreyfus in jail.
Spanish-American War: The USS ''Maine'' explodes and sinks in Havana harbor, Cuba, for then-unknown reasons, killing 266 men.  This event helps lead the United States to declare war on Spain.
The term American Empire is coined in San Francisco.
Robert Allison of Port Carbon, Pennsylvania, becomes the first person to buy an American-built automobile when he buys a Winton automobile that had been advertised in ''Scientific American''.
The Sabi Game Reserve in South Africa, the first officially designated game reserve, is created.
Spanish-American War: The United States Navy begins a blockade of Cuban ports and the USS ''Nashville'' captures a Spanish merchant ship.
Spanish-American War: The United States declares war on Spain the U.S. Congress announces that a state of war has existed since April 21 (later backdating this one more day to April 20).
Spanish-American War ampndash Battle of Manila Bay: Commodore Dewey destroys the Spanish squadron. The first battle of the war, as well as the first battle in the Philippines Campaign.

May 9 ampndash Bava-Beccaris massacre: Hundreds of demonstrators are killed when General Fiorenzo Bava-Beccaris orders troops to fire on a rally in Milan, Italy (in 1900, King Umberto I of Italy is killed in an act of vengeance for his praise of the shooting).
The first games of the Italian Football League are played.
Bombardment of San Juan, the first major battle of the Puerto Rico Campaign during the Spanish-American War.
The territory of Kwang-Chou-Wan is leased by China to France, according to the Treaty of 12 April 1892, as the ''Territoire de Kouang-Tchéou-Wan'', forming part of French Indochina.
Secondo Pia takes the first photographs of the Shroud of Turin and discovers that the image on Shroud itself appears to be a photographic negative.
The Trans-Mississippi Exposition World's Fair opens in Omaha, Nebraska.
Philippine Declaration of Independence: General Emilio Aguinaldo declares the Philippines' independence from Spain.
Yukon Territory is formed, with Dawson chosen as its capital.
Spanish–American War: The United States captures Guam making it the first U.S. overseas territory.
Joshua Slocum completes a 3-year solo circumnavigation of the world.
The United States annexes the Hawaiian Islands.
Spanish-American War ampndash Battle of Santiago Bay: Troops under United States General William R. Shafter take the city of Santiago de Cuba from the Spanish.
Spanish-American War: The United States invasion of Puerto Rico begins with a landing at Guánica Bay.
Spanish-American War: Hostilities end between American and Spanish forces in Cuba.
Opening of the Gornergratbahn railway, connecting Zermatt to the Gornergrat.
700 Greeks and 15 Englishmen are slaughtered by the Turks in Heraklion, Greece, leading to the establishment of the autonomous Cretan State.
Caleb Bradham names his soft drink ''Pepsi-Cola''.
Battle of Omdurman: British and Egyptian troops led by Horatio Kitchener defeat Sudanese tribesmen led by Khalifa Abdullah al-Taashi, thus establishing British dominance in the Sudan.
Luigi Lucheni assassinates Empress Elisabeth of Austria-Hungary.
Fashoda incident: A diplomatic dispute between France and the United Kingdom ends in victory for the British.
Empress Dowager Cixi of China engineers a coup d'etat, marking the end of the Hundred Days' Reform the Guangxu Emperor is arrested.
The Vienna University of Economics and Business Administration is founded under the name ''K.U.K. Exportakademie''.
Battle of Sugar Point: Ojibwe tribesmen defeat U.S. government troops in northern Minnesota.
The Phi Mu Alpha Sinfonia Fraternity (then the Sinfonia Club) is founded at the New England Conservatory in Boston.
The first town council is established in Mateur.
Lutheran Church of the Redeemer in Jerusalem is dedicated.
A 2-day blizzard known as the Portland Gale piles snow in Boston, Massachusetts, and severely impacts the Massachusetts fishing industry and several coastal New England towns.
The first of the two Tsavo maneaters is shot by John Henry Patterson the second is killed 3 weeks later, after 135 workers had been killed.
The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending the Spanish-American War.
Marie and Pierre Curie announce discovery of a substance they call ''radium''.
Lord Curzon becomes Viceroy of India.
SK Rapid Wien is founded.
The Tau Kappa Epsilon Fraternity is founded at Illinois Wesleyan University in Bloomington, Illinois.
The United States takes possession of Wake Island.
Anglo-Egyptian Sudan is formed.
Opel Motors opens for business.
The leaders of six Australian colonies meet in Melbourne to discuss the confederation of Australia as a whole.
Emilio Aguinaldo is sworn in as President of the First Philippine Republic.
The Australian Premiers' Conference held in Melbourne agrees that Australia's capital (Canberra) should be located between Sydney and Melbourne.
The Philippine–American War begins as hostilities break out in Manila.
Spanish–American War: A peace treaty between the United States and Spain is ratified by the United States Senate.

February 14 ampndash Great Blizzard of 1899: Freezing temperatures and snow extend well south into North America, including southern Florida. It is the latest in a series of disasters to Florida's citrus industry.
Voting machines are approved by the U.S. Congress for use in federal elections.
Knattspyrnufélag Reykjavíkur (the first football club in Iceland). is established.

In an accident at Grove Hill, Harrow, London, England, Edwin Sewell becomes the world's first driver of a petrol-driven vehicle to be killed his passenger, Maj. James Richer, dies of injuries three days later.
In Afghanistan, Capt. George Roos-Keppel makes a sudden attack on a predatory band of Chamkannis that have been raiding in the Kurram Valley, and captures 100 prisoners with 3,000 head of cattle.
In Washington State, USA, Mount Rainier National Park is established.
Cyclone Mahina sweeps in north of Cooktown, Queensland. A 12 m wave reaches up to 5ampnbspkm inland, leaving over 400 dead.
Felix Hoffmann patents aspirin.
''Bayer'' registers aspirin as a trademark.
The Frankfurter Fußball-Club Victoria von 1899 (prequel for Eintracht Frankfurt) is founded.
At Sing Sing, Martha M. Place becomes the first woman executed in an electric chair.
George Dewey is made Admiral of the US Navy.

Students at the University of California, Berkeley steal the Stanford Axe from Stanford University yelling at leaders following a baseball game, thus establishing the Axe as a symbol of the rivalry between the schools.
Ferencvárosi TC football club is founded.
Esporte Clube Vitória is founded in Salvador, Brazil.
Three times world champion Nacional is founded.
The First Hague Peace Conference was opened in The Hague by Willem de Beaufort, Minister of Foreign Affairs of The Netherlands.
Female outlaw Pearl Hart robs a stage coach {{convert|30|mi|km}} southeast of Globe, Arizona.
The launch of the Harriman Alaska Expedition.
A tornado completely destroys the town of New Richmond, Wisconsin, killing 117 and injuring more than 200.
June 27 ampndash The highest ever recorded individual cricket score, 628 not out, is made by A. E. J. Collins.
Three Denver, Colorado newspapers publish a story (later proved to be a fabrication) that the Chinese government under the Guangxu Emperor is going to demolish the Great Wall of China.
''Mile-a-Minute Murphy'' earns his famous nickname this day, after he becomes the first man to ride a bicycle for one mile (1.6ampnbspkm) in under a minute on Long Island.
America's first juvenile court is established in Chicago.
NEC Corporation is organized as the first Japanese joint venture with foreign capital.
Battle of Togbao: The French Bretonnet–Braun mission is destroyed in Chad, by the warlord Rabih az-Zubayr.
The Newsboys Strike takes place when the Newsies of New York go on strike (strike lasts until August 2).
The first Peace Conference ends with the signing of the Hague Convention.
The Harriman Alaska Expedition ends successfully.
The John Marshall Law School is founded in Chicago
Marshall quotMajorquot Taylor wins the world 1-mile professional cycling championship in Montreal, securing his place as the first African American world champion in any sport.
A hurricane makes landfall in North Carolina's Outer Banks, completely destroying the town of Diamond City.

At least 512 are killed when a debris hill from the Sumitomo Besshi copper mine at Niihama, Shikoku, Japan, collapses after heavy rain 122 houses, a smelting factory, hospital and many other facilities are destroyed.
Mackinder, Ollier and Brocherel make the first ascent of Batian (5,199m ampndash 17,058ampnbspft), the highest peak of Mount Kenya.
Alfred Dreyfus is pardoned.
The Second Boer War: In South Africa, a war between the United Kingdom and the Boers of the Transvaal and Orange Free State erupts.
The Augusta High School Building is completed in Augusta, Kentucky Augusta Methodist College shuts down.
The Alpha Sigma Tau Sorority is founded in Ypsilanti, Michigan.
The Bronx Zoo opens in New York City.

The American Line's {{SS|St. Paul}} becomes the first ocean liner to report her imminent arrival by wireless telegraphy when Marconi's station at The Needles contacts her 66 nautical miles off the coast of England.
The F.C. Barcelona football club is founded.

Philippine–American War ampampndash Battle of Tirad Pass: (ampquotThe Filipino Thermopylaeampquot) General Gregorio del Pilar and his troops are able to guard the retreat of Philippine President Emilio Aguinaldo before being wiped out.

During the new moon, a near-grand conjunction of the classical planets and several binocular Solar System bodies occur.   The Sun, Moon, Mercury, Mars and Saturn are all within 15° of each other, with Venus 5° ahead of this conjunction and Jupiter 15° behind. Accompanying the classical planets in this grand conjunction are Uranus (technically visible unaided in pollution-free skies), Ceres and Pallas.
The A.C. Milan is founded.
Augusta, KY: Augusta High School burns down due to a heating plant failure.
Second Boer War ampndash Battle of Mafeking: The British inflict a crushing defeat on the Boers.
A large standing stone at Stonehenge falls over, the most recent time this has happened.
Hawaii asks for a delegate at the U.S. Republican National Convention.
The first electric bus becomes operational in New York City.
U.S. Secretary of State John Hay announces the Open Door Policy to promote American trade with China.
The United States Census estimates the country's population to be about 70 million people.
Strikes in Belgium and Germany lead to mining riots.
The Irish leader John Edward Redmond calls for a revolt against British rule.
Dr. Henry A. Rowland of Johns Hopkins University announces a theory about the cause of the Earth's magnetism.
Second Boer War: Boers attack the town of Ladysmith, South Africa, killing over 1,000 people.
President William McKinley of the United States places Alaska under military governance.
The first through passenger train goes from Cairo to Khartoum.
The opera ''Tosca'' premieres in Rome, Italy.
The U.S. Senate accepts the British-German treaty of 1899, in which the United Kingdom renounced its claims to the American Samoa portion of the Samoan Islands.
Brigham H. Roberts of Utah is not seated by the U.S. House of Representatives because of his plural marriage.
5,000 Austrian miners go on strike.
The Second Boer War: At the Battle of Spion Kop, Boer troops defeat the British Army.
The Labor League Conference opens in Sydney, Australia, with plans to form a Federal Labor Party. This is spelled quotLaborquot even in Australia.
Boxer Rebellion: Foreign diplomats in Peking, China, demand that the Boxer rebels be disciplined.
The American League of Professional Baseball Clubs is organized in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania with eight founding teams.
Governor William Goebel of Kentucky shot by several assassins.

Governor William Goebel of Kentucky dies of wounds after being shot by several assassins on January 30. Goebel, who had prevailed in a dispute over the winner of the election in November 1899, had been sworn in on his deathbed. The former Secretary of State of Kentucky Caleb Powers is later found guilty in the  conspiracy to kill Goebel.
Strikers in Aachen, Vienna, and Brussels demand an eight-hour working day and higher wages.
The United Kingdom and the United States sign a treaty for the building of a Central American shipping canal across Central America in Nicaragua.
Second Boer War: The British House of Commons' vote of censure over the British government's handling of the war is defeated.
The international arbitration court at The Hague is created when the Netherlands' Senate ratifies an 1899 peace conference decree.
Second Boer War: British troops are defeated by the Boers at Ladysmith.
Dwight F. Davis creates the Davis Cup tennis tournament.
Second Boer War ampndash Battle of Paardeberg: 20,000 British troops invade the Orange Free State.
Second Boer War: The Siege of Kimberley is lifted.
Second Boer War: Battle of Paardeberg: British troops defeat the Boers.
The British Labour Party is formed and Ramsay MacDonald is appointed as its first secretary.
Second Boer War: British military leaders accept the unconditional notice of surrender from Boer General Piet Cronje.
FC Bayern Munich football club is founded.
beginning) ampndash Groups of officials inspect towns around Australia in order to find a location for the new Federal capital.
Two U.S. Navy cruisers are sent to Central America to protect American interests in a dispute between Nicaragua and Costa Rica.
ampquotBaby-farmerampquot Ada Williams is hanged at Newgate Prison for murdering a 21-month old girl.
A coal mine explosion in West Virginia kills 50 miners.
A fire at Buckingham Palace destroys part of its roof.
Londoners celebrate as Queen Victoria makes a rare visit to the city.
Women in Germany demand the right to participate in university entrance exams.
The botanist Hugo de Vries rediscovers Mendel's Laws of Heredity.
The Gold Standard Act is ratified, placing the United States currency on the gold standard.
The British archaeologist Sir Arthur Evans purchases the land on Crete on which the ruins of the palace of Knossos stand. He begins to unearth some of the palace three days later.
The Mayor of New York, Van Wyck, breaks ground for a new underground quotRapid Transit Railroadquot that will link Manhattan with Brooklyn.
The arrival of a Russian naval fleet in Korea causes concern to the Imperial Japanese government.
Over 1,000 tonnes of waste are removed from demolished buildings in Sydney, Australia, in areas affected by an outbreak of the bubonic plague.
In France, the length of a legal workday for women and children is limited to 11 hours.
The Irish Guards are formed by Queen Victoria.
King George of Greece becomes absolute monarch of Crete.
An anarchist shoots at The Prince of Wales during his visit to Belgium.
The Paris World Exhibition opens.
Battle of Kousséri: French forces secure their domination of Chad. Warlord Rabih az-Zubayr is defeated and killed.
The Hull-Ottawa fire in Canada kills seven and leaves 15,000 homeless.
Hawaii becomes an official U.S. territory.
An explosion of blasting powder in a coal mine in Scofield, Utah kills 200.
The second Modern Olympic Games opens in Paris (as part of the Paris World Exhibition).
Second Boer War: The British Army relieves the Siege of Mafeking.
Boxer Rebellion: Boxers destroy three villages near Peking and kill sixty Chinese Christians.
The United Kingdom proclaims a protectorate over Tonga.
Russia invades Manchuria.
Sergeant William Harvey Carney is awarded the Medal of Honor for heroism in 1863, as the first African American to have been awarded this medal.
Second Boer War: The British annex the Orange Free State as the Orange River Colony.
Boxer Rebellion: The Boxers attack Belgians in the Fengtai railway station.
N'Djamena, the capital city of Chad, is founded as ''Fort-Lamy'' by French commander Émile Gentil.
Boxer Rebellion: Peacekeepers from various European countries arrive in China where they join with Japanese forces.
Carrie Nation begins her crusade to demolish saloons.
Second Boer War: British soldiers take Pretoria.
The Reichstag approves a second law that allows the expansion of the German navy.
Boxer Rebellion: Boxers gather about 20,000 people near Peking and kill hundreds of European citizens, including the German ambassador.

A wharf fire at the docks in Hoboken, New Jersey owned by the North German Lloyd Steamship line spreads to German passenger ships ''{{SS|Saale||2}}, {{SS|Main||2}},'' and ''{{SS|Bremen|1897|2}}.''  The fire engulfs the adjacent piers and nearby ships, killing 326 people.
The first zeppelin flight is carried out over Lake Constance near Friedrichshafen, Germany.
The Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act passes the British Parliament.
Queen Victoria gives her royal assent to the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act.
A German cruise liner, the SS ''Deutschland'', breaks the record for the Blue Riband for the first time with an average speed of {{convert|22.4|kn|km/h}}.
The first line of the Paris Métro is opened.
The Robert Charles Riots break out in New Orleans, Louisiana.
King Umberto I of Italy is assassinated by the Italian-born anarchist Gaetano Bresci.
Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon (later Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother) born in London (died 2002)
Boxer Rebellion: An international contingent of troops, under British command, invades Peking and frees the Europeans taken hostage.
A powerful hurricane hits Galveston, Texas killing about 8,000  people.
Philippine-American War: Filipino resistance fighters defeat a large American column in the Battle of Pulang Lupa.
Philippine-American War: Filipinos under Juan Cailles defeat the Americans under Colonel Benjamin F. Cheatham at Mabitac.
In the British general election, the recently formed Labour Party gains two seats. Winston Churchill is also elected to Parliament for the first time.
The first automobile show in the United States opens at New York City's Madison Square Garden.
U.S. presidential election, 1900: Republican incumbent William McKinley is reelected by defeating Democratic challenger William Jennings Bryan.
Max Planck announces his discovery of the law of black body emission, marking the birth of quantum physics.

A train collision in the New York Central Railroad's Park Avenue Tunnel kills 17, injures 38, and leads to increased demand for electric trains and led to the banning of Steam locomotives in the state.
A snowstorm at Mount Hakkoda, northern Honshu, Japan, kills 199 during a military training exercise.
The Carnegie Institution is founded in Washington, DC with a $10 million gift from Andrew Carnegie.
Police and universal suffrage demonstrators are involved in a physical altercation in Brussels.
The Berlin U-Bahn underground is opened.
U.S. President Roosevelt prosecutes the Northern Securities Company for violation of the Sherman Act.
Real Madrid: Real Madrid was founded.
Second Boer War: South African Boers win their last battle over British forces, with the capture of a British general and 200 of his men.
A Circuit Court prevents Thomas Edison from having a monopoly on motion picture technology.
''Electric Theatre,'' the first movie theater in the United States, opens in Los Angeles, California.
A new car speed record of {{convert|74|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} is set in Nice, France, by Leon Serpollet.
A magnitude 7.5 earthquake rocks Guatemala, killing 2,000.
Hibernian FC won the Scottish Cup 1–0 against Glasgow Celtic FC, the last time in their history they have won the competition.
The Commonwealth Public Service Act creates Australia's Public Service.
In Saint Vincent, La Soufrière erupts, devastating the northern portion of the island, killing 2,000 people
In Martinique, Mount Pelée erupts, destroying the town of Saint-Pierre and killing over 30,000.
Alfonso XIII of Spain begins his reign.
Cuba gains independence from the United States.
Lord Rosebery opens London School of Economics.
The Treaty of Vereeniging ends the Second Boer War.
The Anthracite Coal Strike begins in the United States.
The New York Central railroad inaugurates the ''20th Century Limited'' passenger train between Chicago and New York City, New York.
Australia: Female British subjects (with the exception of Asians, Aborigines and Africans) win the vote with the Uniform Franchise Act.
Norwich City Football Club is formed.
Edward VII institutes The Order.
Service of Reclamation within U.S. Geological Survey.
The Rolling Mill Mine disaster in Johnstown, PA kills 112 miners.
Lord Salisbury retires as British prime minister.
The Order of the Garter is conferred on Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria.
St Mark's Campanile in Venice collapses.
Fluminense Football Club is founded in Rio de Janeiro.
100 miners die in a pit explosion in Wollongong, Australia.
Edward VII is crowned King of the United Kingdom.
Theodore Roosevelt becomes the first American President to ride in an automobile when he rides in a Columbia Electric Victoria through Hartford, Connecticut.
A statue of Joan of Arc was unveiled in Saint-Pierre-le-Moûtier.
In Martinique, Mount Pelée erupts again, destroying the town of Morne-Rouge causing 1000 deaths.
The first Borstal (youth offenders' institution) opens in Borstal, Kent, U.K.
In the United States, a five month strike by the  United Mine Workers ends.
American Old West: The second-in-command of Butch Cassidy's Wild Bunch gang, Kid Curry Logan, is sentenced to 20 years hard labor.

DecemberampampndashFebruary 1903 ampampndash Venezuela Crisis, in which Britain, Germany and Italy sustain a naval blockade on Venezuela in order to enforce collection of outstanding financial claims. This prompts the development of the Roosevelt Corollary to the Monroe Doctrine.
The first Aswan Dam on The Nile is completed.
Discovery Expedition: Scott, Shackleton and Wilson reach the furthest southern point reached thus far by man, south of 82°S.
Edward VII of the United Kingdom is proclaimed Emperor of India.
The first west-east transatlantic radio broadcast is made from the United States to England (the first east-west broadcast having been made in 1901).
The Oxnard Strike of 1903 becomes the first time in U.S. history that a labor union is formed from members of different races.
Morris and Rose Michtom introduce the first teddy bear in America.
El Yunque National Forest in Puerto Rico becomes part of the United States National Forest System as the Luquillo Forest Reserve.
Cuba leases Guantanamo Bay to the United States quotin perpetuityquot.
In New York City, the Martha Washington Hotel, the first hotel exclusively for women, opens.
The British admiralty announces plans to build a naval base at Rosyth.
The Ottoman Empire and the German Empire sign an agreement to build the Constantinople-Baghdad Railway.
The University of Puerto Rico is founded.
The Hay-Herran Treaty, granting the United States the right to build the Panama Canal, is ratified by the United States Senate. The Colombian Senate later rejects the treaty.
The oldest Turkish football club, Besiktas JK, is founded in Istanbul.
Fredrikstad Football Club (FFK) is founded in Norway.
A 30-million-msup3/sup landslide kills 70 in Frank, Alberta.
The leading Macedonian Bulgarian revolutionary Gotse Delchev is killed in a skirmish with the Turkish army.
The port of Burgas, Bulgaria opens.
The White Star Liner, ''SS Ionic'', is launched.
The Paris-Madrid race begins, during which at least eight people are killed.
Serbian King Alexander Obrenović and Queen Draga are assassinated.
The Sigma Alpha Iota International Music Fraternity is founded at the University of Michigan School of Music.
The town of Heppner, Oregon, is nearly destroyed by a cloud burst that resulted in a flash flood that kills an estimated 238 people.

19-year-old American socialite Aida de Acosta becomes the first woman to fly a powered aircraft solo when she pilots Santos-Dumont's motorized dirigible, “No. 9”, from Paris to Château de Bagatelle in France.
July 19 ampndash First Tour de France bicycle race, won by Maurice Garin.
The British take over the Fulani Empire.
Dr. Ernst Pfenning of Chicago becomes the first owner of a Ford Model A.
August 23 (July 17ampndashAugust 10, O.S.) ampndash Second Congress of the All-Russian Social Democratic Labour Party held in exile in Brussels, transferring to London.
The Ilinden Uprising, organized by the Secret Macedonian-Adrianople Revolutionary Organization, breaks out in the Ottoman provinces of Macedonia and Adrianople.
Pope Pius X succeeds Pope Leo XIII as the 257th pope.
Paris Metro train fire takes place.
Judiciary Act passed.
The first stock car event is held at the Milwaukee Mile.
Grêmio Foot-Ball Porto-Alegrense is founded in Porto Alegre, Brazil
Edmund Barton steps down as Prime Minister of Australia and is succeeded by Alfred Deakin.
The Wreck of the Old 97 engine at Stillhouse Trestle near Danville, Virginia, which kills 11 people, inspires a ballad and song.
Prussia becomes the first locality to require mandatory drivers licenses for operators of motor vehicles.
October ampampndash Frank Nelson Cole proves that 2ampsupamp67amp/supamp-1 is composite by factoring it as 193,707,721  761,838,257,287 after trying every Sunday for 3 years.
The first modern World Series, pitting the National League's Pittsburgh Pirates against Boston of the American League, begins at Pittsburgh's Exposition Park.
The High Court of Australia sits for the first time.
The Women's Social and Political Union is founded in the UK.
Boston wins its first of seven World Series titles, beating Pittsburgh at their home park, Huntington Avenue Grounds.
Founding of Argentinian football team, Newell's Old Boys in the city of Rosario.
With the encouragement of the United States, Panama proclaims itself independent from Colombia.
The United States recognizes the independence of Panama.
The Russian Social Democratic Labor Party splits into two groups the Bolsheviks (Russian for quotmajorityquot) and Mensheviks (Russian for quotminorityquot).
The Hay-Bunau-Varilla Treaty is signed by the United States and Panama, giving the U.S. exclusive rights over the Panama Canal Zone.
Colorado Governor James Hamilton Peabody sends the state militia into the town of Cripple Creek to break up a miners' strike.
Taj Mahal Palace amp Tower hotel in Bombay opens its doors to guests.
Orville Wright flies an aircraft with a petrol engine at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina in the first documented, successful, controlled, powered, heavier-than-air flight.
Iroquois Theater fire in Chicago kills 600.
The distress signal ''CQD'' is established, only to be replaced 2 years later by ''SOS''.
The first large-scale bodybuilding competition in America takes place at Madison Square Garden in New York City.
Henry Ford sets a new automobile land speed record of 91.37ampampnbspmph.
The Herero Rebellion in German South-West Africa begins.
The Ålesund Fire destroys most buildings in the town of Ålesund, Norway, leaving about 10,000 people without shelter.
The Great Baltimore Fire in Baltimore, Maryland destroys over 1,500 buildings in 30 hours.
A Japanese surprise attack on Port Arthur (Lushun) starts the Russo-Japanese War.
Roger Casement publishes his account of Belgian atrocities in the Congo.
For $10 million, the United States gains control of the Panama Canal Zone.
Sport Lisboa e Benfica is founded in Portugal.
Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany becomes the first person to make a political recording of a document, using Thomas Edison's cylinder.
Russo-Japanese War: Russian troops in Korea retreat toward Manchuria, followed by 100,000 Japanese troops.
80,000 demonstrators gather in Hyde Park, London, to protest against the importation of Chinese labourers to South Africa by the British government.
British expedition to Tibet ampndash Battle of Guru: British troops under Colonel Francis Younghusband defeat ill-equipped Tibetan troops.
The Entente Cordiale is signed between the UK and France.
Longacre Square in Midtown Manhattan is renamed Times Square after ''The New York Times''.
Aleister Crowley begins writing Liber Al vel Legis, better known as The Book of the Law, a text central to Thelema.  He completes this task on April 10.
The Great Toronto Fire destroys much of that city's downtown, but there are no fatalities.
The Australian Labor Party becomes the first such party to gain national government, under Chris Watson.
The Louisiana Purchase Exposition World's Fair opens in St. Louis, Missouri (closes December 1).
U.S. Army engineers begin work on The Panama Canal.
German football club FC Schalke 04 is established.
Pitching against the Philadelphia Athletics, Cy Young of the Boston Americans throws the first perfect game in the modern era of baseball.
GWR 3440 City of Truro becomes the first railway locomotive to exceed 100ampnbspmph.
The Russian minelayer ''Amur'' lays a minefield about {{convert|15|mi|km}} off Port Arthur and sinks Japan's battleship ''Hatsuse'', 15,000 tons, with 496 crew.
The International Federation of Association Football, FIFA, is established.
Alpha Gamma Delta, now an international women's fraternity, is founded by 11 women at Syracuse University.
Irish author James Joyce meets his future wife Nora Barnacle.
A fire aboard the steamboat ''General Slocum'' in New York City's East River kills 1,021.
Eugen Schauman assassinates Nikolai Bobrikov, Governor-General of Finland.
James Joyce walks to Ringsend with Nora Barnacle he later uses this date (Bloomsday) as the setting for his novel ''Ulysses''.
The Danish ocean liner ''SS Norge'' runs aground and sinks close to Rockall, killing 635, including 225 Norwegian emigrants.
June 28 ampampndash The original icon of Our Lady of Kazan was stolen and subsequently destroyed in Russia.
The 1904 Moscow tornado occurs.
The third Modern Olympic Games opens in St. Louis, Missouri, United States as part of the World's Fair.
The Trans-Siberian railway is completed.
British expedition to Tibet: The British expedition under Colonel Francis Younghusband takes Lhasa in Tibet.
Battle of Waterberg: Lothar von Trotha defeats the Herero in German South-West Africa and drives them into the Omaheke desert, start of the Herero and Namaqua Genocide.
Ismael Montes becomes President of Bolivia.
Russo-Japanese War: A Japanese infantry charge fails to take Port Arthur.
Chris Watson resigns as Prime Minister of Australia and is succeeded by George Reid.
British expedition to Tibet: The Dalai Lama signs the Anglo-Tibetan Treaty with Colonel Francis Younghusband.
The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints President Joseph F. Smith issues a ''Second Manifesto'' against polygamy.
New Zealand dolphin Pelorus Jack is individually protected by Order in Council under the Sea Fisheries Act.
Phi Delta Epsilon, the international medical fraternity, is founded by Aaron Brown and eight of his friends at Cornell University Medical College.
Alpha Kappa Psi, the co-ed Professional Business Fraternity, is founded on the campus of New York University
Theta Tau, the Professional Engineering Fraternity, is founded at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis, Minnesota.
Polytechnic University of the Philippines is founded as Manila Business School through the superintendence of the American C.A. O'Reilley.
Russo-Japanese War ampndash Dogger Bank incident: The Russian Baltic Fleet fires on British trawlers it mistakes for Japanese torpedo boats in the North Sea.
The first underground line of the New York City Subway opens.
U.S. presidential election, 1904: Republican incumbent Theodore Roosevelt defeats Democrat Alton B. Parker.
The first successful caterpillar track is made (it later revolutionizes construction vehicles and land warfare).
The St. Petersburg Soviet urges a run on the banks: the attempt fails and the executive committee is arrested.
Charles Dillon Perrine discovers Jupiter's largest irregular satellite, Himalia.
The K.U. or Konservativ Ungdom (Young Conservatives) is founded by Carl F. Herman von Rosen in Denmark.

Theodore Roosevelt announced his quotCorollaryquot to the Monroe Doctrine, stating that the United States would intervene in the Western Hemisphere should Latin American governments prove incapable or unstable.
The Pi Kappa Phi Fraternity is founded at the College of Charleston in Charleston, SC.
The stage play ''Peter Pan, or The Boy Who Wouldn't Grow Up'' premieres in London.
The East Boston Tunnel opens.
In New York City, the first New Year's Eve celebration is held in Times Square.
The Trans-Siberian Railway officially opens after its completion on July 21, 1904.
Russo-Japanese War: The Russian Army surrenders at Port Arthur, China.
The play ''The Scarlet Pimpernel'' opens at the New Theatre in London and begins a run of 122 performances and numerous revivals.
January 9 O.S.) ampndash The Bloody Sunday massacre of Russian demonstrators, at the Winter Palace in Saint Petersburg, helps trigger the abortive Russian Revolution of 1905.
The Cullinan Diamond is found near Pretoria, South Africa at the Premier Mine.
In Christchurch, New Zealand, the Cathedral of the Blessed Sacrament is opened.
At Fremantle, Western Australia, the R.M.S. ''Orizaba'' is wrecked, but all 160 passengers and the mail are saved.
Russo-Japanese War:  The Battle of Mukden begins in Manchuria.
Rotary International is founded.
Australian Conservative leader Richard Butler takes office as Premier of South Australia.
Tsar Nicholas II of Russia agrees to create an elected assembly (the Duma).
U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt begins a full term.
Russo-Japanese War: Russian troops begin to retreat from Mukden after losing 100,000 troops in 3 days.
Russo-Japanese War: The Japanese capture of Mukden (now Shenyang) completes the rout of Russian armies in Manchuria.
Cassie Chadwick is sentenced for 14 years in Cleveland, Ohio for fraud.
Chelsea FC is founded.
Albert Einstein publishes his paper ''On a heuristic viewpoint concerning the production and transformation of light'', in which he explains the photoelectric effect using the notion of light quanta.
Grover Shoe Factory disaster: A boiler explosion, building collapse and fire in Brockton, Massachusetts kills 58.
German Emperor Wilhelm II asserts German equality with France in Morocco, triggering the Tangier or First Moroccan Crisis.
April ampampndash Albert Einstein works on the special theory of relativity as well as the theory of Brownian motion.
Penny post established between the United Kingdom and Australia.
The Simplon Tunnel is officially opened through the Alps.
In India, the  1905 Kangra earthquake  hits the Kangra valley, kills 20,000, and destroys most buildings in Kangra, Mcleodganj and Dharamshala.
''Lochner v. New York'': The Supreme Court of the United States invalidates New York's 8-hour-day law.

Albert Einstein submits his doctoral dissertation ''On the Motion of Small Particles...'', in which he explains Brownian motion. In the course of the year, Einstein publishes four papers, formulates the theory of special relativity and explains the photoelectric effect by quantization. 1905 is regarded as his quotmiracle yearquot.
Mata Hari debuts in Paris.
Las Vegas, Nevada is founded when {{convert|110|acre|km2}}, in what later becomes downtown, are auctioned off.
Kappa Delta Rho is founded in in room 14 of Old Painter Hall at Middlebury College in Middlebury, VT.

May 28 ampndash Russo-Japanese War ampndash Battle of Tsushima: The Japanese fleet under Admiral Heihachiro Togo destroys the Russian fleet under Admiral Zinovi Petrovich Rozhdestvenski in a 2-day battle.
The Norwegian Parliament declares the union with Sweden dissolved, and Norway achieves full independence.
The Charlton Athletic F.C. is founded.
Princess Margaret of Connaught marries Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden, Duke of Skåne (Gustaf VI Adolf of Sweden).
(June 14 according to the Julian calendar): Mutiny breaks out on the Russian ironclad ''Potemkin''.
The Automobile Association is founded in the United Kingdom.
Albert Einstein publishes the article ''On the Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies'' where he reveals his theory of special relativity.
Taft-Katsura Agreement.
Alfred Deakin becomes Prime Minister of Australia for the second time.
Leopold II of Belgium opens the Antwerpen-Centraal railway station
'Ancient Order of Druids' initiate neo-druidic rituals at Stonehenge in England.
August ampampndash Pablo Valencia gets lost in the Sonoran Desert with no water.
The Canadian provinces of Alberta and Saskatchewan are established from the southwestern part of the Northwest Territories.

Russo-Japanese War ampndash Treaty of Portsmouth: In New Hampshire, a treaty mediated by U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt is signed by victor Japan and Russia. Russia cedes the island of Sakhalin and port and rail rights in Manchuria to Japan.
Albert Einstein submits his paper ''Does the Inertia of a Body Depend Upon Its Energy Content?'' in which he develops an argument for the famous equation ''E''ampnbsp=ampnbsp''mc''sup2/sup.
Galatasaray SK is founded.
HMS ''Dreadnought'' is laid down, revolutionizing battleship design and triggering a naval arms race.
The Wright Brothers' third aeroplane (Wright Flyer III) stays in the air for 39 minutes with Wilbur piloting, the first aeroplane flight lasting over half an hour.
Russian Revolution of 1905: The Russian army opens fire in a meeting on a street market in Tallinn, killing 94 and injuring over 200.
Sweden agrees to the repeal of the union with Norway.
Tsar Nicholas II is forced to grant Russia's first constitution, conceding a national assembly (Duma) with limited powers.
October - The Fauvist artists, led by Henri Matisse and André Derain, first exhibit, at the Salon d'Automne in Paris.

The application of the infamous and, from the Finnish perspective, unconstititional, February Manifesto, subordinating the local legislation of the autonomous Grand Principality of Finland to Imperial Russian legislation, is interrupted in the November Manifesto. The Senate of Finland is also ordered to prepare a proposition for a new unicameral representative organ elected in accordance to universal and equal suffrage to replace the outdated Diet of the Estates.
The Province of Alberta, Canada, holds its first general election.
Prince Carl of Denmark becomes King Haakon VII of Norway.
Irish nationalist Arthur Griffith founds Sinn Féin in Dublin as a political party whose goal is independence for all of Ireland.
A bomb kills Frank Steunenberg, ex-governor of Idaho the case leads to a trial against leaders of the Western Federation of Miners.
First performance of Franz Lehár's operetta ''The Merry Widow'', at the Theater an der Wien, Vienna.

Persian Constitutional Revolution: a nationalistic coalition of merchants, religious leaders and intellectuals in Persia forces the shah to grant a constitution and establish a national assembly, the Majlis.
April 7 ampndash Algeciras Conference to resolve the First Moroccan Crisis between France and Germany.
The {{SS|Valencia}} strikes a reef off Vancouver Island, Canada, killing over 100 (officially 136) in the ensuing disaster.
Ecuador-Colombia earthquake (8.8 on the Moment magnitude scale) and associated tsunami.
{{HMS|Dreadnought|1906|6}} is launched and sparks the naval race between Britain and Germany.
Pope Pius X publishes the encyclical ''Vehementer Nos''.
Courrières mine disaster: an explosion in a coal mine in France kills 1,060.
Traian Vuia makes a short flight in a self-propelled, heavier-than-air aircraft.
Mount Vesuvius erupts and devastates Naples.

San Francisco earthquake (estimated magnitude 7.8) on the San Andreas Fault destroys much of San Francisco, California, USA, killing at least 3,000, with 225,000–300,000 left homeless, and $350 million in damages.
In Tsarist Russia, the Fundamental Laws are announced at the first state Duma.
May ampampndash Jack London's novel ''White Fang'' is serialized in ''The Outing Magazine''.
The {{RMS|Lusitania}} is launched in Glasgow. It is the world's largest ship.
The Second Geneva Convention meets.
Alfred Dreyfus is exonerated. He is reinstalled in the French Army on July 21, thus ending the Dreyfus affair.
A magnitude 8.2 earthquake in Valparaíso, Chile leaves approximately 20,000 dead.
The first Victor Victrola, a phonographic record player, is manufactured.
Unable to control a rebellion Cuban President Tomás Estrada Palma requests United States intervention. The subsequent provisional occupation administration lasts until 1909.
Mahatma Gandhi coins the term ''Satyagraha'' to characterize the Non-Violence movement in South Africa.
A typhoon and tsunami kill an estimated 10,000 in Hong Kong.
The first Gordon Bennett Cup in ballooning is held, starting in Paris. The winning team, piloting the balloon ''United States'', lands in Fylingdales, Yorkshire, England.
The Grand Duchy of Finland becomes the first nation to include the right of women to stand as candidates when it adopts universal suffrage.
The Majlis of Iran convenes for the first time.
A United States diplomatic crisis with Japan arises when the San Francisco public school board orders Japanese students to be taught in racially segregated schools.
Imposter Wilhelm Voigt impersonates a Prussian officer and takes over the city hall in Köpenick for a short time.
An aeroplane of Alberto Santos-Dumont takes off at Bagatelle in France and flies 60 meters (200ampnbspfeet). This is the first officially recorded powered flight in Europe..
The Union Minière du Haut Katanga, a Belgian mining trust, is created in the Congo.
''SOS'' becomes an international distress signal.
{{HMS|Dreadnought}}, the first all-big-gun warship, is commissioned.
The first German Imperial Navy submarine, ''U-1'' (launched on August 4), is commissioned.
Reginald Fessenden makes the first radio broadcast: a poetry reading, a violin solo, and a speech.
The world's first feature film, ''The Story of the Kelly Gang'', is released.
The first Montessori school and daycare center for working class children opens in Rome.
An earthquake, in Kingston, Jamaica kills more than 1,000.
March ampampndash The 1907 Romanian Peasants' Revolt results in possibly as many as 11,000 deaths.
At the opening of the new State Duma in St. Petersburg, Russia 40,000 demonstrators are dispersed by Russian troops.

March 16 ampndash Elections to the new Parliament of Finland are the first in the world with woman candidates, as well as the first elections in Europe where universal suffrage is applied. Nineteen women are elected.
The first taxicabs with taxi meters begin operating in London.
The Second Hague Peace Conference is held.
Tiflis bank robbery: Bolsheviks attack a cash-filled bank coach in the centre of Tiflis, Georgia, killing forty people.
The SS ''Columbia'' sinks after colliding with the lumber schooner ''San Pedro'' off Shelter Cove, California, U.S.A., resulting in 88 deaths.
Korea becomes a protectorate of Japan.
August 9 ampndash Robert Baden-Powell leads the first Scout camp on Brownsea Island, England.
The partially completed superstructure of the Quebec bridge collapses entirely, claiming the lives of 76 workers.
Count Alexander Izvolsky and Sir Arthur Nicolson sign the St. Petersburg Convention, which results in the establishment of the Triple Entente.
The passenger liner ''RMS Lusitania'' makes its maiden voyage from Liverpool, England to New York City.
New Zealand and Newfoundland become dominions.
Guglielmo Marconi initiates commercial transatlantic radio communications between his high power longwave wireless telegraphy stations in Clifden Ireland and Glace Bay, Nova Scotia.
Hague Convention revised by (second) Hague Peace Conference (effective 26 January 1910).
Černová tragedy: Fifteen people are shot during the consecration of a Catholic church in Hungary.
November ampampndash The new ampamp largest passenger liner ''RMS Mauretania'' makes its maiden voyage from Liverpool, England to New York City.
Monongah Mining Disaster: A coal mine explosion kills 362 workers in Monongah, West Virginia, United States.
Upon the death of Oscar II, he is succeeded by his son Gustaf V as king of Sweden.
An explosion in a coal mine in Jacobs Creek, Pennsylvania kills 239.
Santa María School massacre. In Chile soldiers fire at striking mineworkers gathered in the Santa María School in Iquique, over 2000 are killed.
Colombia recognizes the independence of Panama.
The last United States troops leave Cuba after being there since the Spanish-American War.
The Anglo-Siamese Treaty of 1909 is signed in Bangkok.
Einar Dessau uses a short-wave radio transmitter, becoming the first radio broadcaster.
The remains of the Báb were placed in his Shrine of the Báb on Mount Carmel in Haifa, Israel.
Serbia accepts Austrian control over Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Sport Club Internacional was founded in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil.
Robert Peary, Matthew Henson, and four Eskimo explorers come within a few miles of the North Pole.
The city of Tel Aviv (then known as Ahuzat Bayit) is founded.
Joan of Arc is beatified in Rome.
The Anglo-Persian Oil Company, now BP, is incorporated.
Sultan of the Ottoman Empire Abdul Hamid II is overthrown and succeeded by his brother, Mehmed V. He is sent to the Ottoman port city of Thessaloniki (Selanik) the next day.

A revolution forces Mohammad Ali Shah, Persian Shah of the Qajar dynasty to abdicate in favor of his son Ahmad Shah Qajar. He proceeds to leave Persia for Imperial Russia, reportedly seeking the assistance of Nicholas II of Russia in regaining the throne.
Louis Bleriot is the first man to fly across the English Channel (thus a large open body of water) in a heavier-than-air craft.
August 2 ampndash quotTragic Weekquot: The city of Barcelona experiences a workers' uprising.
The United States Army Signal Corp Division purchases the world's first military airplane, a Wright Military Flyer, from the Wright Brothers.
Japan and China sign the Jiandao/Gando Treaty, which gives Japan a way to receive railroad concessions in Manchuria.
An earthquake in the Zagreb area leads Andrija Mohorovičić to identify the Mohorovičić discontinuity.
An agreement by Germany, Italy and Switzerland gives the Germans and Italians access to the Gotthard Rail Tunnel.
Korean nationalist An Jung-geun assassinates Ito Hirobumi, a former Prime Minister of Japan, in Harbin, China, in protest of the Japanese annexation of Korea.
In Nicaragua 500 revolutionaries (including 2 Americans) are executed by order of dictator José Santos Zelaya. The United States responds by sending 2 warships.
King Albert I of Belgium succeeds his uncle, Leopold II, on the throne.
January 20 ampndash The first aviation meet to be held in the United States, the 1910 Los Angeles International Air Meet at Dominguez Field, is held near Los Angeles, California.
Boutros Ghali, the first native-born prime minister of Egypt, is assassinated.
March ampampndash An uprising against Ottoman rule breaks out in Albania.
A fire during a barn-dance in Ököritófülpös, Hungary kills 312.
Comet Halley is visible from Earth.
George V becomes King of the United Kingdom upon the death of his father, Edward VII.
The earth passes through the tail of Comet Halley.
The Union of South Africa is created.
The DELAG Zeppelin dirigible, ''Deutschland'', makes the first commercial passenger flight from Friedrichshafen to Düsseldorf in Germany. The flight takes nine hours.

The ballet ''The Firebird'' (''L'Oiseau de feu''), the first major work by Russian composer Igor Stravinsky, commissioned by Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, is premièred in Paris, bringing the composer international fame.
African-American boxer Jack Johnson defeats American boxer James J. Jeffries in a heavyweight boxing match, sparking race riots across the United States.
A wireless telegraph sent from the {{SS|Montrose}} results in the identification, arrest and execution of murderer Dr. Hawley Crippen.
Ottoman forces capture the city of Shkodër to put down the Albanian Revolt of 1910.
August ampampndash Pan-American Union
A fire at the World Exhibition in Brussels destroys exhibitions of Britain and France.
The Japan-Korea Annexation Treaty is signed.
Montenegro is proclaimed an independent kingdom under Nicholas I.
Emperor Sunjong of the Korean Empire abdicates and the country's monarchy is abolished.
The Vatican introduces a compulsory oath against modernism, to be taken by all priests upon ordination.
October ampampndash First publication of infrared photographs, by Professor Robert Williams Wood in the Royal Photographic Society Journal
Portugal becomes a republic King Manuel II of Portugal flees to England.
The hull of the RMS ''Olympic'' is launched at the Harland and Wolff Shipyards in Belfast.
Vajiravudh (Rama VI) is crowned King of Siam, after the death of his father, King Chulalongkorn (Rama V).

The first air flight for the purpose of delivering commercial freight takes place in the United States of America. The flight, made by Wright Brothers pilot Philip Parmalee between Dayton, Ohio and Columbus, Ohio.
Mexican Revolution: Francisco I. Madero proclaims the elections of 1910 null and void, and calls for an armed revolution at 6 p.m. against the illegitimate presidency/dictatorship of Porfirio Díaz.
Eugene B. Ely lands on the deck of  the USS ''Pennsylvania'' stationed in San Francisco harbor, marking the first time an aircraft lands on a ship.
The first official air mail flight takes place from Allahabad, India to Naini, India, when Henri Pequet carries 6,500 letters a distance of 13ampnbspkm.
A fire at the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory in New York City kills 146.
Heike Kamerlingh Onnes discovers Superconductivityvan Delft, D., and Kes, P. The discovery of superconductivity. Physics Today (September 2010), 38–43.
Mexican Revolution: Rebels take Agua Prieta on the SonoraampndashArizona border government troops take the town back April 17 when the rebel leader quotRedquot López is drunk.
Mexican Revolution: Pancho Villa launches an attack against government troops in Ciudad Juarez without Madero's permission the government troops surrender on May 10.
Mexican Revolution: Porfirio Diaz is convinced to resign but does not do so yet.
Mexican Revolution: A peace treaty is signed between Madero' rebels and government troops in Ciudad Juarez.
Mexican Revolution: Government troops fire at anti-Diaz demonstrators in Mexico City, killing about 200 (officials claim only 40).
Mexican Revolution: Porfirio Diaz signs his resignation and leaves for Veracruz on May 31 he leaves for exile in France.
The hull of the RMS Titanic is launched.
Mexican Revolution: Francisco Madero arrives in Mexico City just after a local earthquake.
The presence of the German warship ''Panther'' in the Moroccan port of Agadir triggers the Agadir Crisis.
Hiram Bingham rediscovers Machu Picchu in Peru.
The theft of the ''Mona Lisa'' is discovered in the Louvre.
The French Navy ship ''Liberté'' explodes at anchor in Toulon, France killing around 300 on both ship and the neighbouring area.
Italy declares war on Ottoman Empire.
The Austin Dam breaks, wiping out the town of Austin, Pennsylvania, United States, killing 78.
The Wuchang Uprising starts the Xinhai Revolution that leads to the founding of the Republic of China.
Mexican Revolution: Felix Diaz, nephew of Porfirio Diaz, occupies the port of Veracruz as a sign of rebellion against Madero.
World's first combat aerial bombing mission takes place in Libya during the Italo-Turkish War. Second Lieutenant Giulio Gavotti of Italy drops several small bombs.
Italy annexes Tripoli and Cyrenaica (this act is confirmed by an act of the Italian Parliament on February 25, 1912).

December ampampndash Delhi Durbar held to mark the coronation of King George V of the United Kingdom and Queen Mary as Emperor and Empress of India and the transfer of the capital of the British Raj from Calcutta to Delhi.
Roald Amundsen's expedition reaches the South Pole.
Opening of first exhibition by Der Blaue Reiter group of painters, in Munich.
Sun Yat-sen is elected the Provisional President of the Republic of China.
The Republic of China is proclaimed.
The Scout Association is incorporated throughout the British Commonwealth by Royal Charter.
Old Style December 23, 1911)
Prague Party Conference: Vladimir Lenin and the Bolshevik Party break away from the rest of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party.
Moscow Art Theatre production of ''Hamlet'' opens.
The African National Congress is founded.
British polar explorer Captain Robert Falcon Scott and a team of four become the second expeditionary group to reach the South Pole.
The International Opium Convention is signed at The Hague.
The Qing Dynasty of China, also called the Manchu Dynasty, comes to an end after 268 years.
Italy makes a surprise attack on the Ottoman port of  Beirut, when the  cruiser ''Giuseppe Garibaldi'' and the gunboat ''Volturno'' bombard the harbour.  The attack kills 97 sailors and civilians.
Serbia and Bulgaria secretly sign a treaty of alliance for a term of eight years, with each pledging to come to the defense of the other during war.
Albert Berry is reported to have made the first parachute jump from a flying airplane.
Italian forces are the first to use airships for a military purpose, using them for reconnaissance west of Tripoli, Libya, behind Turkish lines.
Roald Amundsen in Hobart, Tasmania, announces his success in reaching the South Pole the previous December.
French aviator Henri Seimet makes the first nonstop flight from Paris to London, in three hours.
Lawrence Oates, dying member of Scott's South Pole expedition, leaves the tent saying, quotI am just going outside and may be some time.quot
Mayor Yukio Ozaki of Tokyo gives 3,000 cherry trees to be planted in Washington, D.C., to symbolize the friendship between the two countries.
The remaining members of Robert Falcon Scott's South Pole expedition die.
France establishes a protectorate over Morocco.
{{RMS|Titanic}} strikes  an iceberg in the northern Atlantic Ocean. She sinks the following day with the loss of 1517 lives.
Harriet Quimby becomes the first woman to fly across the English Channel.
'Abdu'l-Baha lays the cornerstone for the Baha'i House of Worship in Wilmette, Illinois
The Olympic Games open in Stockholm, Sweden.
In the United Kingdom, the Royal Flying Corps (forerunner of the Royal Air Force) is established.
The Hamburg America Line's {{SS|Imperator}} is launched in Hamburg and is the world's largest ship.
A fire in Istanbul destroys 1,120 buildings.
U.S. Marines land in Cuba.
Carl Laemmle incorporates ''Universal Pictures''.

United States release of Sarah Bernhardt's film ''Les Amours de la reine Élisabeth'' is influential on the development of the movie feature.  Adolf Zukor, who incorporates Paramount Pictures on May 8, 1914, launches his company as the distributor.  Paramount celebrates its centennial in 2012.
Emperor Meiji of Japan dies. He is succeeded by his son Yoshihito who becomes Emperor Taishō. In Japanese History, the event marks the end of the Meiji era and the beginning of the Taishō era.
United States occupation of Nicaragua: U.S. Marines land from the USS ''Annapolis'' in Nicaragua to support the conservative government at its request.
Sultan Abd Al-Hafid of Morocco abdicates.
The Kuomintang, the Chinese nationalist party, is founded.
The First Balkan War begins: Montenegro declares war against Turkey.
Bulgarian pilots Radul Minkov and Prodan Toprakchiev perform the first bombing with an airplane in history, at the railway station of Karaagac near Edirne against Turkey.
Krupp engineers Benno Strauss and Eduard Maurer patent austenitic stainless steel.
Italy and the Ottoman Empire signed a treaty in Ouchy near Lausanne ending the Italo-Turkish War.
Albania declares independence from the Ottoman Empire.
Piltdown Man, thought to be the fossilized skull of a hitherto unknown form of early human, presented to the Geological Society of London. It is revealed to be a hoax in 1953.
Merck files patent applications in Germany for synthesis of the entactogenic drug MDMA (''Ecstasy''), developed by Anton Köllisch.
The First Balkan War ends temporarily: Bulgaria, Greece, Montenegro, and Serbia (the Balkan League countries) sign an armistice with Turkey, ending the two-month-long war.
British Board of Film Censors receives the authority to classify and censor films.
Ulster Volunteer Force established to fight against Irish Home Rule.
General election in Tasmania.
House of Lords rejects Irish Home Rule Bill for the second time.
New York City's Grand Central Terminal, having been rebuilt, reopens as the world's largest train station.
The 16th Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified, authorizing the Federal government to impose and collect income taxes.
Mexican Revolution: Begins the episode known as ''La Decena Trágica'', the rebellion of some military chiefs against the President Francisco I. Madero.
Mexican Revolution: Assassination of President Francisco I. Madero and Vice President José María Pino Suárez. Is succeeded by General Victoriano Huerta.
March
The House of Romanov celebrates the 300th anniversary of its succession to the throne, amidst an outpouring of monarchist sentiment in Russia.
Following the assassination of his rival Song Jiaoren, Yuan Shikai uses military force to dissolve China's parliament and rules as a dictator.
Woodrow Wilson succeeds William Howard Taft as the 28th President of the United States.
March 7 ampndash First Battle of Bud Dajo: American troops decisively defeat Moro rebels in the Philippines.
Australia begins building the new federal capital of Canberra.
Mexican Revolution: Pancho Villa returns to Mexico from his self-imposed exile in the United States.
The Uruguayan Air Force is founded.
King George I of Greece is assassinated after 50 years on the throne. He is succeeded by his son Constantine.
Sung Chiao-jen, a founder of the Chinese nationalist party (KMT), is wounded in an assassination attempt and dies 2 days after.
Mexican Revolution: Venustiano Carranza announces his Plan of Guadalupe, and begins his rebellion against Victoriano Huerta's government as head of the ''Constitutionals''.
Balkan War: Bulgarian forces take Adrianople.
The Seventeenth Amendment to the United States Constitution is passed, dictating the direct election of senators.
RMS Aquitania, built by John Brown amp Company, is launched on the Clyde.
''Raja Harishchandra'', the first full-length Indian feature film is released, marking the beginning of the Indian film industry.
Igor Sikorsky becomes the first person to pilot a 4-engine aircraft.
New York Governor William Sulzer approves the charter for the Rockefeller Foundation, which begins operations with a $100,000,000 donation from John D. Rockefeller.
The first Chelsea Flower Show held in London.
First Balkan War: A peace treaty is signed in London, ending the war.
The Greek-Serbian Treaty of Alliance is signed, paving the way for the Second Balkan War.
Emily Davison, a British suffragette, runs out in front of the King's horse, Anmer, at the Epsom Derby. She is trampled and dies 4 days later in the hospital, never having regained consciousness.

The Deutsches Stadion in Berlin is dedicated with the release of 10,000 pigeons, in front of an audience of 60,000 people.  It has been constructed especially for the 1916 Summer Olympics, which are cancelled as a result of World War I.
Bud Bagsak Massacre: U.S. troops under General John 'Black Jack' Pershing kill at least 2,000 civilians in Bud Bagsak, the Philippines.
Joseph Cook becomes the 6th Prime Minister of Australia.
The Second Balkan War begins.
Town Foundation of San Javier, Rio Negro, Uruguay.
In China, the province of Chungking declares independence Chinese Republican forces crush the rebellion in a couple of weeks.
Macedonia is divided after the Second Balkan War, according to the Treaty of Bucharest.
Invention of stainless steel by Harry Brearley in Sheffield
{{convert|700|ft|m}} above Buc, France, parachutist Adolphe Pegoud jumps from an airplane and lands safely.
The statue of ''The Little Mermaid'' is unveiled in Copenhagen.
The Dublin Lock-out begins in Ireland all trade union members are dismissed.
September 9  ampndash In Germany, BASF starts worlds first plant for the production of fertilizer, based on the Haber-Bosch process, feeding today about 1/3 of the worlds population.
In Chicago, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith is founded, with Sigmund Livingston as its first president.
French aviator Roland Garros crosses the Mediterranean in an airplane flying from Fréjus, France to Bizerte, Tunisia.
Second Balkan War: A peace treaty is signed in Constantinople between the Ottoman Empire and the Kingdom of Bulgaria.
Mexican Revolution: Pancho Villa's troops take Torreón after a 3-day battle, when government troops retreat.
SS ''Volturno'' catches fire and sinks in the North Atlantic.
U.S. President Woodrow Wilson triggers the explosion of the Gamboa Dike, ending construction on the Panama Canal.
An explosion at the Universal Colliery, Senghenydd in South Wales kills 439 miners, the worst mining accident in the United Kingdom.
HMS ''Queen Elizabeth'' launched at Portsmouth Dockyard as the first oil-fired battleship.
The DLRG (German Life-Saving Society) is founded.
The Lincoln Highway, the first automobile road across the United States, is dedicated.
The insane King Otto of Bavaria is deposed by his cousin, Prince Regent Ludwig, who assumes the title Ludwig III.
Mohandas Gandhi is arrested while leading a march of Indian miners in South Africa.
11 ampndash The Great Lakes Storm of 1913 kills more than 250.
Fédération Internationale d'Escrime, the international organizing body of competitive fencing is founded in Paris, France.
December ampampndash The Gateway of India is constructed in Bombay, to commemorate Queen Victoria's reign as Empress of India.

The Ford Motor Company introduces the first moving assembly line, reducing chassis assembly time from 12½ hours in October to 2 hours, 40 minutes (although Ford is not the first to use an assembly line, his successful adoption of one sparks an era of mass production).
Crete, having obtained self rule from Turkey after the first Balkan War, is annexed by Greece.
Vincenzo Perugia tries to sell the ''Mona Lisa'' in Florence and is arrested.
Arthur Wynne's quotword-crossquot, the first crossword puzzle, is published in the ''New York World''.
The Federal Reserve is created by Woodrow Wilson.
In the Italian Hall Disaster, seventy-three men, women, and children are trampled to death when someone falsely yells quotfirequot at a crowded Christmas party.
Italy returns the ''Mona Lisa'' to France.
